subject: "Why the f**k should you care about software art?" - giving a talk
content:
Hey HackSphere,

"Why the f**k should I care about software art?"

I'll be trying to answer this question and why it motivated me to quit my software engineering job and pursue a fulltime freelance career as a software artist.

If this sounds interesting to you, come to my talk next Tuesday at 7pm, hosted at The Midway SF<https://www.facebook.com/Themidwaysf/?fref=mentions&__xts__%5B0%5D=68.ARALdp-obUmXzfSSLf6PQyvDJ34TH5fc5uwdpoJwCcdz-oaU869YQYBrgPM_JCXoY1Dz8gDpF-I5s2yg3ixDsb6sKEwcbITPnOowmYve3AU8UwqL8CthEclpE3xRQ3dXLoIqahQkN5ydfC6lkvWY-NCJcFMf8EryJ40TQYP5-7OE-6lG0YABrNQ&__tn__=K-R> (900 Marin St, San Francisco, CA 94124). Fellow artist Donald Hanson<https://www.facebook.com/donald.hans0n?fref=mentions&__xts__%5B0%5D=68.ARALdp-obUmXzfSSLf6PQyvDJ34TH5fc5uwdpoJwCcdz-oaU869YQYBrgPM_JCXoY1Dz8gDpF-I5s2yg3ixDsb6sKEwcbITPnOowmYve3AU8UwqL8CthEclpE3xRQ3dXLoIqahQkN5ydfC6lkvWY-NCJcFMf8EryJ40TQYP5-7OE-6lG0YABrNQ&__tn__=K-R> will also be there presenting his work! Would love to see you there!

Thanks,
Xiaohan Zhang
www.hellochar.com
801-413-9872
html_content:
Hey HackSphere,

 

"Why the f**k should I care about software art?"

 

I'll be trying to answer this question and why it motivated me to quit my software engineering job and pursue a fulltime freelance career as a software artist.

 

If this sounds interesting to you, come to my talk next Tuesday at 7pm, hosted at The Midway SF (900 Marin St, San Francisco, CA 94124). Fellow artist Donald Hanson will also be there presenting his work! Would love to see you there!

 

Thanks,
Xiaohan Zhang
www.hellochar.com
801-413-9872

On Tue, Dec 11, 2012 at 5:25 PM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:
A connected idea from CJ (like a week ago)
I have an idea for something wonderful. It's called Hacker Santa. It is along the lines of your hackathonprojects idea. It is a website where kids (or adults) can go and submit ideas for hackers to build at hackathons (or otherwise). It would be primarily for inspiring kids and making their ideas come true. Example: Little Xander dreams of a fire-breathing t-rex controlled by electric guitar. LordDeath27 is a musician and engineer, loves the idea, and wants to make it happen. He builds it, posts a video, and dedicates it to Xander, who is now up in the stratosphere of happiness thanks to his hero. It:
1) adds to the number of good ideas for hacks (especially when there is a ). Kids have great ideas. 
2) empowers kids by having their imaginations influence the real world, 
3) brings joy to kids and brings heroism to hackers, and 
4) inspires kids to become hackers/creatives/engineers themselves. 
I'd like to make connections with educators. I know a few math and physics teachers, and I could start with them. It is simple enough that could easily fit into a teaching curriculum and could make the idea of learning math/physics/computers more exciting. Growing up I had no role models for the kind of thing we do, fictional or not. Hackers should be in "What do you want to be when you grow up?" books along with astronauts and firemen.

A connected idea from CJ (like a week ago)

I have an idea for something wonderful. It's called Hacker Santa. It is
along the lines of your hackathonprojects idea. It is a website where kids
(or adults) can go and submit ideas for hackers to build at hackathons (or
otherwise). It would be primarily for inspiring kids and making their ideas
come true. Example: Little Xander dreams of a fire-breathing t-rex
controlled by electric guitar. LordDeath27 is a musician and engineer,
loves the idea, and wants to make it happen. He builds it, posts a video,
and dedicates it to Xander, who is now up in the stratosphere of happiness
thanks to his hero. It:
1) adds to the number of good ideas for hacks (especially when there is a
). Kids have great ideas.
2) empowers kids by having their imaginations influence the real world,
3) brings joy to kids and brings heroism to hackers, and
4) inspires kids to become hackers/creatives/engineers themselves.
I'd like to make connections with educators. I know a few math and physics
teachers, and I could start with them. It is simple enough that could
easily fit into a teaching curriculum and could make the idea of learning
math/physics/computers more exciting. Growing up I had no role models for
the kind of thing we do, fictional or not. Hackers should be in "What do
you want to be when you grow up?" books along with astronauts and firemen.



On Mon, Dec 10, 2012 at 8:29 PM, emperorcj <emperorcj@gmail.com> wrote:

> instantly catalyze their awesome*




-- 
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970

subject: Gift Economy Entrepreneur
content:
Yeah! I declare myself a gift economy entrepreneur. 

One definition of entrepreneur: one who who shifts resources out of an area 
of lower and into an area of higher productivity and greater yield. 

But instead of the end goal being profit: the goal is greater awesomeness 
and greater inspiration in the world. 

I use journals as my example. The benefits of writing in a journal are 
great, and it is not hard to start. If one is not in the habit of writing 
down things which inspire them, they are missing out on a simple 
improvement on awesomeness. 

Journals are an inexpensive enough resource that I could carry around 
several. Upon meeting the people who need it most, those whose activation 
energy is ripe for the benefits of journal writing, I could instantly 
catalyze their 

Furthermore, I could put my friends' art on the cover (the gift of art, the 
gift of using your art). Perhaps on the inside cover I could find a poem or 
quote, written by my friends. 

This is the magic of gift economy. One recognizes that others would benefit 
from the gift of X, and makes the connection. 

Another gift is the gift of remix. Remixing art. Remixing an idea. A 
response to one's idea with a further elaboration of an idea. The gift of 
connection. Connecting one person to another. Connecting one person to a 
journal, or to a new perspective. 

The gift economy entrepreneur innovates upon methodologies for remixing and 
connecting, so that it may be done efficiently: so that great numbers of 
people may be inspired, in great ways. 

The gift economy entrepreneur innovates upon DIY techniques to lower the 
requirements of resources, time, and money, to deliver the maximum amount 
of awesome and inspiration.
html_content:
Yeah! I declare myself a gift economy entrepreneur. 

One definition of entrepreneur: one who who shifts resources out of an area of lower and into an area of higher productivity and greater yield. 

But instead of the end goal being profit: the goal is greater awesomeness and greater inspiration in the world. 

I use journals as my example. The benefits of writing in a journal are great, and it is not hard to start. If one is not in the habit of writing down things which inspire them, they are missing out on a simple improvement on awesomeness. 

Journals are an inexpensive enough resource that I could carry around several. Upon meeting the people who need it most, those whose activation energy is ripe for the benefits of journal writing, I could instantly catalyze their

Furthermore, I could put my friends' art on the cover (the gift of art, the gift of using your art). Perhaps on the inside cover I could find a poem or quote, written by my friends. 

This is the magic of gift economy. One recognizes that others would benefit from the gift of X, and makes the connection. 

Another gift is the gift of remix. Remixing art. Remixing an idea. A response to one's idea with a further elaboration of an idea. The gift of connection. Connecting one person to another. Connecting one person to a journal, or to a new perspective. 

The gift economy entrepreneur innovates upon methodologies for remixing and connecting, so that it may be done efficiently: so that great numbers of people may be inspired, in great ways. 

The gift economy entrepreneur innovates upon DIY techniques to lower the requirements of resources, time, and money, to deliver the maximum amount of awesome and inspiration.

Sorry, that last sentence was unclear:
Secondly, I have experimented to see if I can get lights behind my lens to appear to float in front of the lens like the reflections of the ceiling lights (see attached), but with no luck


On Fri, Jun 14, 2013 at 6:48 PM, Jacob Cole <jcole@mit.edu> wrote:
Yes! I'm a huge fan of the "touch the spring" parabolic mirror illusion exhibit in science museums!

I mention holography because there's an additional really weird and awesome effect that this particular fresnel lens exhibits that I think might be similar in origin to those printed hologram cards -- there always appears to be a vividly 3d orb floating over the lens when you view it from one side. But I don't think that's modifiable. (See attached.)

Secondly, I have experimented with my lens to see If I can get images behind to appear to float like the reflections of the lights above (see attached), but with no luck. Is there more than trivial convex lens optics going on in creating the illusion do you think?
Thanks,





On Fri, Jun 14, 2013 at 4:44 PM, V. Michael Bove Jr. <vmb@media.mit.edu> wrote:
Strictly speaking, this doesn't have anything to do with real holography (you're doing geometric optics, not diffractive optics).

Do you know about the "parabolic mirror illusion"?  (look it up)

You might be able to use that for some of what you're thinking about.

If you want to do something with lenses, there's a decent and brief explanation of image formation at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lens_(optics)#Imaging_properties

Best,
Michael Bove

I found a Fresnel lens of just such a focus that, when you hold it in front of you, images of lights on the ceiling in the room reflect off of it and appear to be floating in space on top of the lens like a hologram. subject: Reminder: Code challenge to win free SF trip
content:
University Hacker Olympics is having its qualifying coding challenge again!
Do well, and get a free trip to the hackathon, which features dozens of
companies. I went last year, and it was pretty fun.

The Coding Challenge Qualifiers will be on Sunday, April 7th in N52 (3rd
floor) from 6:0010 p.m. (you can arrive a little early to enjoy food). The
challenge* can also be taken online as well,* so don't worry about N52
being far, but *register so I can send you day-of details*.

Last year it was solving sudoku puzzles in the least number of lines of
code (but it will be better this year, and possibly involve APIs). If you
are a current Junior/Masters/PhD student, then you will be taking the
challenges this month to qualify for the September 2013 event.
Freshmen/Sophomores will be competing for the IAP hackathon.


RSVP here: bit.ly/YOzB5c, so I can buy enough food and drinks.

You don't need to do it twice if you already have.

-- 
*

Bruno Brasil Ferrari Faviero
MIT Class of 2015
C: (561) 929-8444
*
html_content:
University Hacker Olympics is having its qualifying coding challenge again! Do well, and get a free trip to the hackathon, which features dozens of companies. I went last year, and it was pretty fun.

The Coding Challenge Qualifiers will be on Sunday, April 7th in N52 (3rd floor) from 6:0010 p.m. (you can arrive a little early to enjoy food). The challenge can also be taken online as well, so don't worry about N52 being far, but register so I can send you day-of details.

Last year it was solving sudoku puzzles in the least number of lines of code (but it will be better this year, and possibly involve APIs). If you are a current Junior/Masters/PhD student, then you will be taking the challenges this month to qualify for the September 2013 event. Freshmen/Sophomores will be competing for the IAP hackathon.


RSVP here: bit.ly/YOzB5c, so I can buy enough food and drinks.

You don't need to do it twice if you already have.


--

Bruno Brasil Ferrari Faviero
MIT Class of 2015
C: (561) 929-8444

subject: Hackathon this Saturday in Menlo Park!
content:
Housemates and I at http://incepto.house are hosting a hackathon this
Saturday in Menlo Park! Our official topic is "Society of Agents" - how
does Minsky's Society of Mind interface with modern AI Agents? And what can
that inspire? But we're open minded.

Event: https://lu.ma/0m9qby4j

We ended up with way more interest than we initially expected, with over
127 people RSVPed, and we may host an overflow group at another house in
Atherton :)

(Also, if you know anyone who might want to be a sponsor, it would be great
to have a VC or startup willing to pitch in to cover our costs; it's a
great recruiting/scouting opportunity.)

Ping me in reply here if you want to participate, and I will shortlist you!

--
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970
html_content:
Housemates and I at http://incepto.house are hosting a hackathon this Saturday in Menlo Park! Our official topic is "Society of Agents" - how does Minsky's Society of Mind interface with modern AI Agents? And what can that inspire? But we're open minded.

Event: https://lu.ma/0m9qby4j

We ended up with way more interest than we initially expected, with over 127 people RSVPed, and we may host an overflow group at another house in Atherton :)

(Also, if you know anyone who might want to be a sponsor, it would be great to have a VC or startup willing to pitch in to cover our costs; it's a great recruiting/scouting opportunity.)

Ping me in reply here if you want to participate, and I will shortlist you!

package within it.

It's a little like an ORM for canvas, including touch, type, and mouse

It's a lot faster to develop in than D3, and is especially good if you're
trying to do things that D3 is not so strong in (like working with small
data sets, or not much data at all)

subject:
Re: Best tools for coding dynamic drawings? (no preference for
 language or platform)
content:
You could try Sketchpad by Ivan Sutherland. It only runs on the Lincoln
TX-2, since it is written in TX-2 MACRO Mark IV, an assembly language
specific to that single computer; and the code may only be available on
microfiche. But hey, you said you have *no preference* for language or
platform (;

As far as modern computers go, I would bet that D3/js is your best choice.
For static drawings, I prefer TikZ/TeX, and for applications that are
heavier on compute than visualization fanciness I use SDL (and sometimes
Cairo) from C, but I doubt either of these would best meet your needs.

@davidad
On Aug 14, 2014 8:40 AM, "Daniel Windham" <dewindham@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hi Hacksphere,
>
> We've discussed graph and data visualization tools (e.g. this thread
> <https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/hacksphere/d3/hacksphere/Z2tZfzo2Lvw/U5C8tnBEbJ8J>)
> but I'm looking for more general computer drawing tools. Such a tool should
> facilitate programming of arbitrary 2D geometric drawings and animations
> and allow keyboard and cursor user interaction mediated through associated
> logic. As one detail, easily customized snap points would be great.
>
> D3 in the javascript/HTML world is a good bet, certainly, but are there
> even better things? What else is out there?
>
> Thanks,
> Daniel
>
> --
> You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups
> "HackSphere" group.
> To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an
> email to HackSphere+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.
> For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.
>
html_content:
You could try Sketchpad by Ivan Sutherland. It only runs on the Lincoln TX-2, since it is written in TX-2 MACRO Mark IV, an assembly language specific to that single computer; and the code may only be available on microfiche. But hey, you said you have *no preference* for language or platform (;

As far as modern computers go, I would bet that D3/js is your best choice. For static drawings, I prefer TikZ/TeX, and for applications that are heavier on compute than visualization fanciness I use SDL (and sometimes Cairo) from C, but I doubt either of these would best meet your needs.

@davidad

On Aug 14, 2014 8:40 AM, "Daniel Windham" <dewindham@gmail.com> wrote:
Hi Hacksphere,

We've discussed graph and data visualization tools (e.g. this thread) but I'm looking for more general computer drawing tools. Such a tool should facilitate programming of arbitrary 2D geometric drawings and animations and allow keyboard and cursor user interaction mediated through associated logic. As one detail, easily customized snap points would be great.

D3 in the javascript/HTML world is a good bet, certainly, but are there even better things? What else is out there?

Thanks,
Daniel

subject:
Best tools for coding dynamic drawings? (no preference for language
 or platform)
content:
Hi Hacksphere,

We've discussed graph and data visualization tools (e.g. this thread
<https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/hacksphere/d3/hacksphere/Z2tZfzo2Lvw/U5C8tnBEbJ8J>)
but I'm looking for more general computer drawing tools. Such a tool should
facilitate programming of arbitrary 2D geometric drawings and animations
and allow keyboard and cursor user interaction mediated through associated
logic. As one detail, easily customized snap points would be great.

D3 in the javascript/HTML world is a good bet, certainly, but are there
even better things? What else is out there?

Thanks,
Daniel
html_content:
Hi Hacksphere,

We've discussed graph and data visualization tools (e.g. this thread) but I'm looking for more general computer drawing tools. Such a tool should facilitate programming of arbitrary 2D geometric drawings and animations and allow keyboard and cursor user interaction mediated through associated logic. As one detail, easily customized snap points would be great.

D3 in the javascript/HTML world is a good bet, certainly, but are there even better things? What else is out there?

Thanks,
Daniel

subject: Re: It’s totally unsustainable that all the communication networks are currently walled gardens
content:
Unsustainable in what sense? Any non-open option provides minimal
incentives to convince others to move, so once market dominance is achieved
(or perceived threat from upstarts is higher than perceived benefit from
the marginal users who would be acquired) incentives point towards walls,
particularly as openness is non-trivial for low-knowledge users to easily
benefit from. I'm not saying it's not great for users, but I don't see
these incentives changing in the immediate future.

I tried re-imagining logarithms as being a left hand exponent and made a table of some common things. It feels a bit more clear to me (especially in that it's closely tied to exponentials), but perhaps not. The power rule is the most confusing in the new notation (but not more so than it usually looks perhaps?). What do you think?




On 9 May 2014 14:31, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
What if we had a notation for logarithms that was as nice as our notation for exponentiation? Maybe math with logarithms would become much easier.



————————————————————————————————————
Rafael Cosman, Stanford CS 2015

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael’s Schedule

Here are two awesome projects that I’m working on, both related to CS-education: Cosmos and Code Camp

subject:
Pre-seed Founder friend looking for advisors and board members in
 eldercare/fintech
content:
Hey hacksphere, 

I'm sure some of you know her, but my friend Lily is closing her pre-seed 
round in an elder care/fintech Startup and is looking for advisors or 
experts in the field that would be willing to talk or chat with her. If 
you're interested, shoot her an email at lvittayarukskul@gmail.com

Here is the company she's building:

Waterlily is rebuilding the architecture for family caregiving, so that 
when you unexpectedly need to step in to care for your aging parent, it is 
actually sustainable and affordable. We’re building a membership 
marketplace in eldercare to outcompete in the $627B life insurance industry 
while also capturing an estimated $10B of the severely underserved $280B 
family caregiving industry. Founded by Lily Vittayarukskul, a startup 
veteran having served 4 startups across product and engineering, AI, data 
science, and sales, holding both IC and leadership positions. Lily’s formal 
training started early, at 14, when she started college part-time, leading 
her to dual genetics and data science degrees from UC Berkeley, and her 
training at NASA’s JPL when she was 16.
html_content:
Hey hacksphere, 

I'm sure some of you know her, but my friend Lily is closing her pre-seed round in an elder care/fintech Startup and is looking for advisors or experts in the field that would be willing to talk or chat with her. If you're interested, shoot her an email at lvittayarukskul@gmail.com

Here is the company she's building:

Waterlily is rebuilding the architecture for family caregiving, so that when you unexpectedly need to step in to care for your aging parent, it is actually sustainable and affordable. We’re building a membership marketplace in eldercare to outcompete in the $627B life insurance industry while also capturing an estimated $10B of the severely underserved $280B family caregiving industry. Founded by Lily Vittayarukskul, a startup veteran having served 4 startups across product and engineering, AI, data science, and sales, holding both IC and leadership positions. Lily’s formal training started early, at 14, when she started college part-time, leading her to dual genetics and data science degrees from UC Berkeley, and her training at NASA’s JPL when she was 16.

subject: Hiring Bay Area DevOps and other positions
content:
Hi HackSphere,

Hope everyone is being well.

Our infrastructure developer Dora Factory has recently closed a new strategic
round
<https://hackernoon.com/dora-factory-closes-new-strategic-raise-announces-new-ecosystem-partnerships>,
led by dao5, Singapore's Whampoa Group (Lee & Lee), and several others.

We will be expanding our team in the Bay Area over the next a few months,
and we are looking for following positions:

- Blockchain Infrastructure DevOp Engineer / SRE Engineer
- Blockchain Developer (experience in CosmosSDK related tech stack
preferred)
- BD / Venture Analyst

For the rest of our open positions, check out our jobs page
<https://jobs.lever.co/DoraHacks>.

If you have friends who are interested in building blockchain infra for
decentralized governance and open source communities, feel free to refer /
reach out!

Best,

Jiannan
html_content:
Hi HackSphere,

Hope everyone is being well.

Our infrastructure developer Dora Factory has recently closed a new strategic round, led by dao5, Singapore's Whampoa Group (Lee & Lee), and several others.

We will be expanding our team in the Bay Area over the next a few months, and we are looking for following positions:

- Blockchain Infrastructure DevOp Engineer / SRE Engineer
- Blockchain Developer (experience in CosmosSDK related tech stack preferred)
- BD / Venture Analyst

For the rest of our open positions, check out our jobs page.

If you have friends who are interested in building blockchain infra for decentralized governance and open source communities, feel free to refer / reach out!

Best,

Jiannan

subject: Oracle Help!
content:
I have some Oracle questions from a friend.

(note: this is translated from Japanese and I myself know nothing about
Oracle so they might not make the most sense)

is it possible to change the "LAST_NUMBER" instance in an Oracle sequence
without rewriting the whole thing? perhaps using the "ALTER" function?

apparently this has something to do with the fact that Oracle is an
"automatically numbering" indexical system or something, and regular
updating methods do not work

apologies for the vagueness of the question but any help is appreciated
html_content:
I have some Oracle questions from a friend.

(note: this is translated from Japanese and I myself know nothing about Oracle so they might not make the most sense)

is it possible to change the "LAST_NUMBER" instance in an Oracle sequence without rewriting the whole thing? perhaps using the "ALTER" function?

apparently this has something to do with the fact that Oracle is an "automatically numbering" indexical system or something, and regular updating methods do not work

apologies for the vagueness of the question but any help is appreciated

subject: Re: Logarithms
content:
Elainas use is much much better than the current uses outlined on stack exchange.
I especially like the way the product rule for logs now comes naturally from the rule for multiplying polynomials with the same base.
This needs to become the standard!  (Although it may mean more bracketing due to more frequent ambiguous expressions)

Regards,

David

subject: Saturday Night Code; the tradition starts now
content:
Before beginning MIT, my roommate (friend from high school) Prabhav said to
me: you know what Jacob? Every Saturday we're going to get together and
code and it's going to be epic. And we did, and it was epic, we produced
such things as instadefine.com and admitsphere.org .

But what we really wanted, the reason we came to MIT, was not to sit in our
rooms, but to go learned from the massively skilled people around us. This
is why came we to MIT in the first place. This is a tradition I want to do
the legwork to start before I graduate.

The tradition is starting now.

To join us for the really casual Saturday Night code event we're putting
together today. It's going to be 6-12 pm on the 5th floor of the student
center, migrating into the SIPB office at 8 or possibly earlier.

 Add yourself and your interests to the people tab of
http://ideapad.io/saturday-night-code if you want to come, so people with
related interests can find you. Also, please invite people who would be
interested! Finally, feel free to call me at 8587406970

Finally, here are some beginning databases of ideas:
ideapad.io/hackathon-ideas
http://ideapad.io/sipb-project-ideas
Add your own, and connect with others!

Excited!
-- 
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970
html_content:
Before beginning MIT, my roommate (friend from high school) Prabhav said to me: you know what Jacob? Every Saturday we're going to get together and code and it's going to be epic. And we did, and it was epic, we produced such things as instadefine.com and admitsphere.org .

But what we really wanted, the reason we came to MIT, was not to sit in our rooms, but to go learned from the massively skilled people around us. This is why came we to MIT in the first place. This is a tradition I want to do the legwork to start before I graduate. 

The tradition is starting now. 

To join us for the really casual Saturday Night code event we're putting together today. It's going to be 6-12 pm on the 5th floor of the student center, migrating into the SIPB office at 8 or possibly earlier.

 Add yourself and your interests to the people tab of http://ideapad.io/saturday-night-code if you want to come, so people with related interests can find you. Also, please invite people who would be interested! Finally, feel free to call me at 8587406970

Finally, here are some beginning databases of ideas:
ideapad.io/hackathon-ideas
http://ideapad.io/sipb-project-ideas
Add your own, and connect with others!

Excited!
--
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970

I apologize to any who were consumed by the raw awesomeness of that novel :) I should have warned you. I cringe while writing this, but he does have a bunch of other excellent short stories. Here is one that explores a really interesting moral dilemma --

Thanks so much for Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality Rafael!!!

http://www.fanfiction.net/s/5782108/1/Harry_Potter_and_the_Methods_of_Rationality 

On Sat, May 26, 2012 at 10:53 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@gmail.com> wrote:
I'll add this work by Eliezer Yudkowsky -- a deep argument for rationality masquerading as a the world's best piece of Harry Potter fan fiction. Highly recommended. Reading this made me a Bayesian and a Futurist.

http://www.fanfiction.net/s/5782108/1/Harry_Potter_and_the_Methods_of_Rationality

Cheers!
Daniel

subject: Hack with the legendary Feross Aboukhadijeh!
content:
Hey guys, my friend Feross, originally from Stanford, famed for getting
1,000,000 users in a few days with ytinstant.com, founder of
https://peercdn.com which got bought by Yahoo, and who has become such a
legendary hacker he's now a quora topic, is working on a fantastic
open-source project and would like nothing more than to find  a great,
really enthusiastic collaborator. He's happy to mentor them. Would you be
willing to help us find him one by thinking of your friends who might be
interested and by emailing out to any relevant lists you know of? Or join
him yourself!

His product's description:
WebTorrent <https://webtorrent.io/> is a torrent client that works in the
browser! YEP, THAT'S RIGHT. THE BROWSER. It's written completely in
JavaScript – the language of the web – and uses WebRTC (data channels) for
true peer-to-peer transport without browser plugins, extensions, or
installations.

Imagine a peer-to-peer YouTube where viewers help to host the site's
content. By making BitTorrent easier to use, we can get more people to
participate and take the first steps to re-decentralizing
<http://redecentralize.org/> the Internet.

You can see WebTorrent in action and use it to send a file to a friend
here: https://instant.io

-- 
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970
html_content:
Hey guys, my friend Feross, originally from Stanford, famed for getting 1,000,000 users in a few days with ytinstant.com, founder of https://peercdn.com which got bought by Yahoo, and who has become such a legendary hacker he's now a quora topic, is working on a fantastic open-source project and would like nothing more than to find  a great, really enthusiastic collaborator. He's happy to mentor them. Would you be willing to help us find him one by thinking of your friends who might be interested and by emailing out to any relevant lists you know of? Or join him yourself!

His product's description:
WebTorrent is a torrent client that works in the browser! YEP, THAT'S RIGHT. THE BROWSER. It's written completely in JavaScript – the language of the web – and uses WebRTC (data channels) for true peer-to-peer transport without browser plugins, extensions, or installations.

Imagine a peer-to-peer YouTube where viewers help to host the site's content. By making BitTorrent easier to use, we can get more people to participate and take the first steps to re-decentralizing the Internet.

You can see WebTorrent in action and use it to send a file to a friend here: https://instant.io

--
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970

content:

feed, don't they? No need to reinvent the proverbial wheel.

This is going in parallel with an idea matching algorithm which suggests relevant ideas.

Jiannan

subject: real-time news data scraping
content:
Hi HackSphere!

We are trying to make a general suggestion engine. One part of this is a
real-time news suggestion & summarization site, what are the good tools /
api to scrape news papers from multiple sites?

This is going in parallel with an idea matching algorithm which suggests
relevant ideas.

Jiannan
html_content:
Hi HackSphere! 

We are trying to make a general suggestion engine. One part of this is a real-time news suggestion & summarization site, what are the good tools / api to scrape news papers from multiple sites?

This is going in parallel with an idea matching algorithm which suggests relevant ideas.

Jiannan

subject: Re: Curiosity
content:
Definitely following this, pretty awesome mission.

If you haven't seen the animation of the landing
sequence<http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BudlaGh1A0o>,
it's worth watching. This is the first time that the "sky crane" landing
mechanism has been tried, and it should be pretty thrilling!

Success is far from guaranteed. Only America has successfully landed
anything on Mars. Russia has tried 9
times<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exploration_of_Mars#Timeline_of_Mars_exploration>,
and 8 of them failed. The one other, Mars 3, was a lander that they heard
back from for just 15 seconds on the surface of Mars before it died.

Yea, the odyssey orbiter had a sticky reaction wheel, which are pretty cool
devices for adjusting attitude on small satellites. We'll still know within
a few hours!

Doug

On Sat, Jul 21, 2012 at 3:32 PM, Matt Vernacchia <vernamatt@gmail.com>wrote:

> need to provide a communication relay. Odyssey can provide a live relay at
> 8kb/s, but MRO has a store-and-forward setup, so it will record the landing
> transmissions from MSL, but will only be able to send them on to earth
> after the landing has finished.I believe MRO is in position, but Odyssey
> had an anomaly while trying to alter its orbit to get over the landing
> site. I think they will try again early next week, and will announce on the
> 25th whether they will have live communications for the landing.

html_content:
Definitely following this, pretty awesome mission.

If you haven't seen the animation of the landing sequence, it's worth watching. This is the first time that the "sky crane" landing mechanism has been tried, and it should be pretty thrilling!

Success is far from guaranteed. Only America has successfully landed anything on Mars. Russia has tried 9 times, and 8 of them failed. The one other, Mars 3, was a lander that they heard back from for just 15 seconds on the surface of Mars before it died.

Yea, the odyssey orbiter had a sticky reaction wheel, which are pretty cool devices for adjusting attitude on small satellites. We'll still know within a few hours!

Doug

On Sat, Jul 21, 2012 at 3:32 PM, Matt Vernacchia <vernamatt@gmail.com> wrote:
i'm not working on MSL, so I wont have any "insider info", but ill keep you posted on what I do hear.
The latest news I've heard is regarding communications. The landing site will be out of view of earth at the time of the landing, so one of the NASA satilites around Mars - Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) or Odyssey - will need to provide a communication relay. Odyssey can provide a live relay at 8kb/s, but MRO has a store-and-forward setup, so it will record the landing transmissions from MSL, but will only be able to send them on to earth after the landing has finished.I believe MRO is in position, but Odyssey had an anomaly while trying to alter its orbit to get over the landing site. I think they will try again early next week, and will announce on the 25th whether they will have live communications for the landing.

subject: Re: Software to help with Software transitions
content:
yeah dude a hotkey trainer for all apps would be invaluable

Shadi Barhoumi
(650) 255 - 7536

On March 17, 2014 at 5:37:19 AM, Rafael Cosman (rafaelc@stanford.edu) wrote:

We all make transitions in the software that we use. It might be useful to have a tool for making these transitions smoother.

I’ve recently moved from Sublime to Atom, but I still often open Sublime by accident. Just out of habit, or because an extensions is still associated with Sublime. I don’t want to remove Sublime from my system (because I expect I may still need it in the future, and it’s still a great piece of software that I’m proud to have) but I want help remembering to use Atom instead of Sublime. Because I’ve made a conscious decision to make this switch, my computer should help me.

Imagine a simple application where I select “Transition from [Sublime] -> [Atom]” (those are drop down menus) and then it will help me to use Atom whenever I would have otherwise used Sublime. Like whenever Sublime would open, instead this application makes a popup saying 

“Are you sure you want to open this file in Sublime? Atom may be a better choice”
buttons: [Use Sublime]   [Use Atom]

Rev2 of this software will train you to use the new hotkeys whenever you try to use the old ones. Thankfully with Atom/Sublime the hotkeys are almost identical.



— Rafa

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858

subject: Re: Software to help with Software transitions
content:
Boom! Specifying arbitrary intentions to your computer. This could be like If This Than That but it would work locally on your own machine.


Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael's Schedule

From: H. Lee howonlee@stanford.edu
Reply: hacksphere@googlegroups.com hacksphere@googlegroups.com
Date: March 17, 2014 at 8:40:23 AM
To: hacksphere@googlegroups.com hacksphere@googlegroups.com
Subject:  Re: Software to help with Software transitions  

Let's try the Lally paper.

Best Regards,
Howon Lee


On Mon, Mar 17, 2014 at 8:34 AM, H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
This is a concrete instance of the abstract problem of habit change.

The literature has the most general method of habit change, due to Gollwitzer. It's called an implementation intention, and it's pretty ridiculous:

Say,

"If ___ (condition),

I will ____ (action)"

A concrete example comes from one of Gollwitzer's experiment with heroin addicts. If you ask a heroin addict to compose a CV for you, they have a success rate at doing this of about 0 percent. If you ask them to say, "If ___ (a condition that involves a specific time and place), I will write the CV", lots of them did. Gollwitzer apparently habitually promotes this thing, but here it is: http://www.psych.nyu.edu/gollwitzer/01BrandLengGoll_ActInit.pdf

If you think it's ridiculous, you should just try it. The caveat is those sample sizes!

I've studied this at some length, actually, so you can ask questions. Probably another interesting point is the regressions that Phillipa Lally did for how long it takes to form a habit: 15 to 250 days (250 days is an extrapolation, the study lasted 84 days). Most her papers are pretty cool (http://www.ucl.ac.uk/hbrc/diet/lallyp.html). This is How are habits formed: Modelling habit formation in the real world. That paper, I don't have any annoying methodological problems with, but I did a "ooh, cool charts!" reading of that one. I'm not sure about how to get it without journal access, so if you're interested in reading it for yourself, you should reply back or something. (I dunno: are attachments possible for Google Groups?)

There's an interesting piece of misinformation floating around about how it takes 21 days. Actual experience should tell you that's a load of crock, but the source of the factoid is interesting. A plastic surgeon named Maxwell Maltz noticed that his patients recovered from the self-image difference from plastic surgery about 21 days after the surgery, and talked to other surgeons about it, getting a bunch of anecdotal evidence that people generally do that for non-plastic surgeries as well. He also did the reading on Norbert Weiner's cybernetics, and therefore concluded that the self-image was a self-regulatory process a la cybernetics. Reasonable, but the timeframe for the habit was fairly off.

The other interesting part about Maltz is that he started promulgating this idea that visualization has this modality of action where it will do everything for you. Actually, he gives a lot of examples of visualization being excellent fake practice, for which there's a lot of good evidence. So The Secret and other scummy books like it are intellectual heritors of this book.

Probably the best individual book for actually reading about habit change is Baumeister's Willpower, it's a good lay reading. The less lay reading is The Handbook of Self-Regulation, edited by Baumeister and co. You can find that on the internet fairly easily.

(this is what I do instead of studying for finals...)

Best Regards,
Howon Lee

On Mon, Mar 17, 2014 at 8:34 AM, H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
This is a concrete instance of the abstract problem of habit change.

The literature has the most general method of habit change, due to Gollwitzer. It's called an implementation intention, and it's pretty ridiculous:

Say,

"If ___ (condition),

I will ____ (action)"

A concrete example comes from one of Gollwitzer's experiment with heroin addicts. If you ask a heroin addict to compose a CV for you, they have a success rate at doing this of about 0 percent. If you ask them to say, "If ___ (a condition that involves a specific time and place), I will write the CV", lots of them did. Gollwitzer apparently habitually promotes this thing, but here it is: http://www.psych.nyu.edu/gollwitzer/01BrandLengGoll_ActInit.pdf

If you think it's ridiculous, you should just try it. The caveat is those sample sizes!

I've studied this at some length, actually, so you can ask questions. Probably another interesting point is the regressions that Phillipa Lally did for how long it takes to form a habit: 15 to 250 days (250 days is an extrapolation, the study lasted 84 days). Most her papers are pretty cool (http://www.ucl.ac.uk/hbrc/diet/lallyp.html). This is How are habits formed: Modelling habit formation in the real world. That paper, I don't have any annoying methodological problems with, but I did a "ooh, cool charts!" reading of that one. I'm not sure about how to get it without journal access, so if you're interested in reading it for yourself, you should reply back or something. (I dunno: are attachments possible for Google Groups?)

There's an interesting piece of misinformation floating around about how it takes 21 days. Actual experience should tell you that's a load of crock, but the source of the factoid is interesting. A plastic surgeon named Maxwell Maltz noticed that his patients recovered from the self-image difference from plastic surgery about 21 days after the surgery, and talked to other surgeons about it, getting a bunch of anecdotal evidence that people generally do that for non-plastic surgeries as well. He also did the reading on Norbert Weiner's cybernetics, and therefore concluded that the self-image was a self-regulatory process a la cybernetics. Reasonable, but the timeframe for the habit was fairly off.

The other interesting part about Maltz is that he started promulgating this idea that visualization has this modality of action where it will do everything for you. Actually, he gives a lot of examples of visualization being excellent fake practice, for which there's a lot of good evidence. So The Secret and other scummy books like it are intellectual heritors of this book.

Probably the best individual book for actually reading about habit change is Baumeister's Willpower, it's a good lay reading. The less lay reading is The Handbook of Self-Regulation, edited by Baumeister and co. You can find that on the internet fairly easily.

(this is what I do instead of studying for finals...)

Best Regards,
Howon Lee


On Mon, Mar 17, 2014 at 5:37 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
We all make transitions in the software that we use. It might be useful to have a tool for making these transitions smoother.

I’ve recently moved from Sublime to Atom, but I still often open Sublime by accident. Just out of habit, or because an extensions is still associated with Sublime. I don’t want to remove Sublime from my system (because I expect I may still need it in the future, and it’s still a great piece of software that I’m proud to have) but I want help remembering to use Atom instead of Sublime. Because I’ve made a conscious decision to make this switch, my computer should help me.

Imagine a simple application where I select “Transition from [Sublime] -> [Atom]” (those are drop down menus) and then it will help me to use Atom whenever I would have otherwise used Sublime. Like whenever Sublime would open, instead this application makes a popup saying 

“Are you sure you want to open this file in Sublime? Atom may be a better choice”
buttons: [Use Sublime]   [Use Atom]

Rev2 of this software will train you to use the new hotkeys whenever you try to use the old ones. Thankfully with Atom/Sublime the hotkeys are almost identical.



— Rafa

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael's Schedule

subject: Re: Interactive Art: crowdsourced music video
content:
Haha thanks Neal.

I want to see a real-time version with a suggestion engine for
pictures/videos and captioned instructions. Every 10-60 seconds a new goal
would get picked from user-generated ideas and everyone on the site would
collaborate towards the goal (or anti-collaborate if they were
mischievous). That would be a cool hackathon project. Though of course,
this is just a simple MMOG.

subject: Re: Google Keep
content:
I use OneNote for everything.  I just started on a tablet PC back in 2008 and have never looked around at something else.

It works well, though is a huge disk hog.

Sent from my iPhone

On Apr 19, 2014, at 6:33 PM, "Neil Satra" <neil.satra@gmail.com<mailto:neil.satra@gmail.com>> wrote:

Integration is off to a good start, with quick note-taking ability on Android, and everything being synced across devices through Google Drive, thus giving a nice, consistent web interface to it too. Personally, I've switched over from using crappy Evernote everywhere to OneNote on the Surface Pro and Keep on my phone.

I haven't seen any numbers on traction.


On Sun, Apr 20, 2014 at 2:10 AM, Michael Plasmeier <plaz@theplaz.com<mailto:plaz@theplaz.com>> wrote:
I wonder if this is gaining traction?

Its >1 year old, but it is not well integrated with other Google properties, making it fairly orphaned.

Does anyone know?

From: HackSphere@googlegroups.com<mailto:HackSphere@googlegroups.com> [mailto:HackSphere@googlegroups.com<mailto:HackSphere@googlegroups.com>] On Behalf Of Song, Max
Sent: Saturday, April 19, 2014 6:02 PM
To: Rafael Cosman
Cc: hacksphere
Subject: Re: Google Keep

shiny

On Fri, Apr 18, 2014 at 7:06 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu<mailto:rafaelc@stanford.edu>> wrote:
Consider using it for your notes and todo-lists : )

https://drive.google.com/keep/




Rafael Cosman, Stanford CS 2015

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858<tel:858-775-2858>

I want to be better tomorrow than I am today, so Im totally open to feedback at all times.
Dont hesitate to write to me to let me know what I do well and how I can do better.

Android, and everything being synced across devices through Google Drive,
thus giving a nice, consistent web interface to it too. Personally, I've
switched over from using crappy Evernote everywhere to OneNote on the
Surface Pro and Keep on my phone.

I haven't seen any numbers on traction.

html_content:
Integration is off to a good start, with quick note-taking ability on Android, and everything being synced across devices through Google Drive, thus giving a nice, consistent web interface to it too. Personally, I've switched over from using crappy Evernote everywhere to OneNote on the Surface Pro and Keep on my phone.

I haven't seen any numbers on traction.


On Sun, Apr 20, 2014 at 2:10 AM, Michael Plasmeier <plaz@theplaz.com> wrote:

I wonder if this is gaining traction?

 

It’s >1 year old, but it is not well integrated with other Google properties, making it fairly orphaned.

 

Does anyone know?

subject: Re: Logarithms
content:
Wow. This is really cool! Helps understand some things more intuitively.

I like this! We have both `exp` and `log` for when the parameters are
enormous, and the clearer superscripts when they're manageable.

Wow. This is really cool! Helps understand some things more intuitively.

I like this! We have both `exp` and `log` for when the parameters are enormous, and the clearer superscripts when they're manageable.

Hmm

http://math.stackexchange.com/questions/314809/super-or-subscript-notation-on-the-left-hand-side-of-a-symbol

Best Regards,
Howon Lee


On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 3:41 PM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
#THIS #IS #AWESOME

Like one of the coolest things I’ve seen in a long time. Eliana, really great work!

Seeing this makes me curious: Is there an equivalent of base change for regular exponentiation?

————————————————————————————————————
Rafael Cosman, Stanford CS 2015

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael’s Schedule

Here are two awesome projects that I’m working on, both related to CS-education: Cosmos and Code Camp
————————————————————————————————————

From: Eliana Lorch elianalorch@gmail.com
Reply: Eliana Lorch elianalorch@gmail.com
Date: May 9, 2014 at 3:24:44 PM
To: Rafael Cosman rafaelc@stanford.edu
Cc: Gary Antonick antonick@stanford.edu, hackhex hackhex@googlegroups.com
Subject:  Re: Logarithms

I tried re-imagining logarithms as being a left hand exponent and made a table of some common things. It feels a bit more clear to me (especially in that it's closely tied to exponentials), but perhaps not. The power rule is the most confusing in the new notation (but not more so than it usually looks perhaps?). What do you think?




On 9 May 2014 14:31, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
What if we had a notation for logarithms that was as nice as our notation for exponentiation? Maybe math with logarithms would become much easier.



————————————————————————————————————
Rafael Cosman, Stanford CS 2015

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael’s Schedule

Here are two awesome projects that I’m working on, both related to CS-education: Cosmos and Code Camp

subject: Re: Interesting people building cool products + free pizza!
content:
They had hack hours every week or so during the school year. I know one of
the guys who organizes this, and he says it'll be a regular thing.

Best Regards,
Howon Lee

On Fri, Jul 13, 2012 at 11:59 AM, Neal Wu <nealwu@college.harvard.edu>wrote:

Could stable coins solve this?

Rafael - I've heard of a group (forgot the name) that's experimenting with airdropping stablecoins to mobile phones in places without strong fiat. I think refugees are part of the target group as well, since they might not have any form of identification or access to bank accounts from their home country.

On Sun, 3 Mar 2019 at 16:00, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Jacob— I think that's interesting. I'd love to learn more about the regulations in the US around that. I'm surprised that it's allowed given that it's creating currencies that compete with the US dollar for commerce (as opposed to TrueUSD which is just another form of USD, similar to Venmo).

Jiannan— Security tokens are an application that we're looking into and we're starting to form partnerships there. But the actual volume of security tokens right now is still very small.

Co-Founder
TrustToken - We're hiring!

A big set of applications that I’m looking into now is to use stable coins to buy and trade security tokens.

Jiannan

Sent from my iPhone

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

 
On Fri, Mar 1, 2019 at 8:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Hey Hacksphere, our team has launched one of the largest USD stablecoins, TrueUSD, and grown it to about $200mm in the last year. (A stablecoin is a price-stable cryptocurrency. Every TrueUSD is backed by a US Dollar sitting in a big bank account.)

We're looking to launch several other tokenized currencies this year and are thinking about the possible applications that these products could unlock, including forex, remittances, and much more.

I'd love to get thoughts on what applications you see for tokenized fiat currencies such as TrueUSD, TrueGBP, etc.

Best,
Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu
Co-Founder
TrustToken - We're hiring!

html_content:
Could stable coins solve this?

On Wed, Mar 6, 2019 at 10:21 AM Eric Liu <ericsliu@gmail.com> wrote:
Rafael - I've heard of a group (forgot the name) that's experimenting with airdropping stablecoins to mobile phones in places without strong fiat. I think refugees are part of the target group as well, since they might not have any form of identification or access to bank accounts from their home country.

On Sun, 3 Mar 2019 at 16:00, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Jacob— I think that's interesting. I'd love to learn more about the regulations in the US around that. I'm surprised that it's allowed given that it's creating currencies that compete with the US dollar for commerce (as opposed to TrueUSD which is just another form of USD, similar to Venmo).

Jiannan— Security tokens are an application that we're looking into and we're starting to form partnerships there. But the actual volume of security tokens right now is still very small.


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu
Co-Founder
TrustToken - We're hiring!


On Sat, Mar 02, 2019 at 5:10 AM, Jiannan Zhang <jn.zhang610@gmail.com> wrote:
A big set of applications that I’m looking into now is to use stable coins to buy and trade security tokens.

Jiannan

Sent from my iPhone

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

 
On Fri, Mar 1, 2019 at 8:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Hey Hacksphere, our team has launched one of the largest USD stablecoins, TrueUSD, and grown it to about $200mm in the last year. (A stablecoin is a price-stable cryptocurrency. Every TrueUSD is backed by a US Dollar sitting in a big bank account.)

We're looking to launch several other tokenized currencies this year and are thinking about the possible applications that these products could unlock, including forex, remittances, and much more.

I'd love to get thoughts on what applications you see for tokenized fiat currencies such as TrueUSD, TrueGBP, etc.

Best,
Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu
Co-Founder
TrustToken - We're hiring!

subject: Re: What application for Stablecoins do you see?
content:
Might be worth looking at tokenizing currencies in developing countries or countries with less liquid currency markets due to currency controls. Many of the financial derivative products available with USD are not available to those trading currencies such as the Malaysian Ringgit. 

Seems like tokenizing fiat right now is a form of legal arbitrage or more accessible money market fund, I am curious to learn what other applications there will be.

On Sun, Mar 03, 2019 at 7:30 PM, Lawrence Wang <l@lw.io> wrote:
Jacob—

MakerDAO just prototyped this at ETHDenver with a version of its Dai stablecoin called Buffidai, that was set up so attendees could spend it on the food vendors, but only the vendors could convert it back to normal Dai.

Also, you should check out the story of Sardex if you haven’t already.
On Sun, Mar 3, 2019 at 4:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Jacob— I think that's interesting. I'd love to learn more about the regulations in the US around that. I'm surprised that it's allowed given that it's creating currencies that compete with the US dollar for commerce (as opposed to TrueUSD which is just another form of USD, similar to Venmo).

Jiannan— Security tokens are an application that we're looking into and we're starting to form partnerships there. But the actual volume of security tokens right now is still very small.


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu
Co-Founder
TrustToken - We're hiring!


On Sat, Mar 02, 2019 at 5:10 AM, Jiannan Zhang <jn.zhang610@gmail.com> wrote:
A big set of applications that I’m looking into now is to use stable coins to buy and trade security tokens.

Jiannan

Sent from my iPhone

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

 
On Fri, Mar 1, 2019 at 8:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Hey Hacksphere, our team has launched one of the largest USD stablecoins, TrueUSD, and grown it to about $200mm in the last year. (A stablecoin is a price-stable cryptocurrency. Every TrueUSD is backed by a US Dollar sitting in a big bank account.)

We're looking to launch several other tokenized currencies this year and are thinking about the possible applications that these products could unlock, including forex, remittances, and much more.

I'd love to get thoughts on what applications you see for tokenized fiat currencies such as TrueUSD, TrueGBP, etc.

Best,
Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu
Co-Founder
TrustToken - We're hiring!

On Sun, Mar 03, 2019 at 7:30 PM, Lawrence Wang <l@lw.io> wrote:
Jacob—

MakerDAO just prototyped this at ETHDenver with a version of its Dai stablecoin called Buffidai, that was set up so attendees could spend it on the food vendors, but only the vendors could convert it back to normal Dai.

Also, you should check out the story of Sardex if you haven’t already.
On Sun, Mar 3, 2019 at 4:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Jacob— I think that's interesting. I'd love to learn more about the regulations in the US around that. I'm surprised that it's allowed given that it's creating currencies that compete with the US dollar for commerce (as opposed to TrueUSD which is just another form of USD, similar to Venmo).

Jiannan— Security tokens are an application that we're looking into and we're starting to form partnerships there. But the actual volume of security tokens right now is still very small.

TrustToken - We're hiring!


On Sat, Mar 02, 2019 at 5:10 AM, Jiannan Zhang <jn.zhang610@gmail.com> wrote:
A big set of applications that I’m looking into now is to use stable coins to buy and trade security tokens.

Jiannan

Sent from my iPhone

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

 
On Fri, Mar 1, 2019 at 8:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Hey Hacksphere, our team has launched one of the largest USD stablecoins, TrueUSD, and grown it to about $200mm in the last year. (A stablecoin is a price-stable cryptocurrency. Every TrueUSD is backed by a US Dollar sitting in a big bank account.)

We're looking to launch several other tokenized currencies this year and are thinking about the possible applications that these products could unlock, including forex, remittances, and much more.

I'd love to get thoughts on what applications you see for tokenized fiat currencies such as TrueUSD, TrueGBP, etc.

Best,
Raf

Co-Founder

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

I'd love to get thoughts on what applications you see for tokenized fiat currencies such as TrueUSD, TrueGBP, etc.

Best,

On Fri, Aug 17, 2012 at 1:15 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:
How do we make "Philosophy 2.0?"

Hi all! 
A few rough thoughts I wanted to share :

I'm trying to organize the goals of the nation, the goals our government ought to be inspiring us to achieve, into sets of progress bars of increasing specificity, and I'd love your thoughts. Some of my thoughts are attached -- how would you structure the vision you have for a prosperous society in a framework like this?

I have a couple rough examples of goals structured in this format:
Utopia
-Prosperity
---abundant, fulfilling play-work 
-Health
---healthcare for all
-Happiness
-Tranquility


Turn Men Into Kings
-Dishwasher
-Healthcare
-Good Food
-Access to people
people's goals?

Thought: study beautiful dreams and the mechanics of dreams become real through the lens of literature (the bildunsroman (coming of age story)/fairy tales and fantasy literature?) as basis for creating a genuinely beautiful future for ourselves

Relatedly (as I've mentioned) I'm trying to make a database of intentions people have, things they want to do. I'm starting with programming project ideas, and I seek to organize them on a connected graph. Eventually, all peoples intentions/visions/dreams could be organized into a system like this.
http://hackathonprojects.tk/   
(Very rough) Aspirational Graph :http://instadefine.com/IdeaOverflow/IdeaGrapher%20FishEye/VisionCharter0.2.htm 

--
Jacob

subject: StartX Applications Open
content:
For those interested in startup accelerators, StartX gets my highest
recommendation. Their application is now open:*


 Serious about your Startup?

StartX Applications are Now Open!

Founders Apply Now<http://startx.stanford.edu/apply?utm_source=StartX&utm_medium=Email&utm_content=Round1&utm_campaign=P13Applicants>

To learn more about StartX, RSVP for the info session
here<https://docs.google.com/a/sse.stanford.edu/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dEJPaUNob2puTXNpT05SVUdvelo2emc6MQ>
.

[image: Inline image 1]
StartX accelerates the development of Stanford's top entrepreneurs through
experiential education and collective intelligence.  Our companies have
collectively raised over $100M with an 85% funding rate, and are at the
cutting edge of a wide range of industries, including consumer IT, medical
and hardware. Benefits of being a StartX founder:

   - Community of talented and motivated Stanford entrepreneurs
   - No equity or fees
   - Free office space and legal services, including incorporation costs
   - Mentorship from experienced entrepreneurs and business leaders
   including:


   - Konstantin Guericke (co-founder LinkedIn)
      - Mike Cassidy (sold company for $500M in 500 days)
   - Jerry Yang (Founder of Yahoo)
      - Reid Hoffman (Founder of Paypal and LinkedIn)
      - Vinod Khosla (Founder of Sun Microsystems)
      - George Zachary (First investor in Twitter, Yammer)
      - John Lilly (ex-CEO of Mozilla, Partner of Greylock)
      - Joe Lonsdale (Founder Palantir, Addepar)
      - and many more...


   - Over $100,000 in free resources and access to Silicon Valley's top
   investors.


Come to our info session this Friday, February 1st from 5-6pm at the
d.school<https://maps.google.com/maps?q=stanford+d.school&ie=UTF-8&ei=cswIUZyOAaLoigKCxoHACg&ved=0CAsQ_AUoAA>to
find out more about the value
StartX will provide to you as you found your company.

RSVP for the info session
here<https://docs.google.com/a/sse.stanford.edu/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dEJPaUNob2puTXNpT05SVUdvelo2emc6MQ>
.
*

subject: Re: Thanks
content:
Regarding the Gestalt-loop closing news source - it's worth examining
current news disseminators who come close to your idea but are not
completely there yet.

1. The Guardian (UK news publisher) sometimes releases "story trackers" -
essentially, a single page which aggregates separate news stories relating
to a topic. The fact that all of the news stories come from the same
publisher makes integration simple and clean, and it appears that they make
an attempt at comment integration. Unfortunately, this article mentions
that the Guardian only tracks science stories.
http://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2010/jun/09/science-story-trackers

2. When the Boston Marathon bombings were underway, there were many story
trackers out there, some run by news publishers, and some run by
independent bloggers. The ability to aggregate all of the stories with
opinions and minor updates of an event as it unfolds is crucial. Here is
one example blogger who tracked the bombings.
http://ksj.mit.edu/tracker/2013/04/boston-marathon-developing-story

3. We have Wikinews, which enables collaborative editing of individual news
stories. They don't have collaboratively edited story trackers. This is a
great area of opportunity - we can repurpose collaboratively edited story
trackers to follow entire issues, such as the attempt to make healthcare
more accessible to Americans, from start to finish. A terrific way of
closing open Gestalts.

I feel some ideas coming together. If anyone would like to work with me to
design and prototype a web app which fills this function, let me know.

-JamesFW

Olin College '15
https://github.com/jimmyfw

html_content:
Regarding the Gestalt-loop closing news source - it's worth examining current news disseminators who come close to your idea but are not completely there yet.

1. The Guardian (UK news publisher) sometimes releases "story trackers" - essentially, a single page which aggregates separate news stories relating to a topic. The fact that all of the news stories come from the same publisher makes integration simple and clean, and it appears that they make an attempt at comment integration. Unfortunately, this article mentions that the Guardian only tracks science stories.
http://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2010/jun/09/science-story-trackers

2. When the Boston Marathon bombings were underway, there were many story trackers out there, some run by news publishers, and some run by independent bloggers. The ability to aggregate all of the stories with opinions and minor updates of an event as it unfolds is crucial. Here is one example blogger who tracked the bombings.
http://ksj.mit.edu/tracker/2013/04/boston-marathon-developing-story

3. We have Wikinews, which enables collaborative editing of individual news stories. They don't have collaboratively edited story trackers. This is a great area of opportunity - we can repurpose collaboratively edited story trackers to follow entire issues, such as the attempt to make healthcare more accessible to Americans, from start to finish. A terrific way of closing open Gestalts.

I feel some ideas coming together. If anyone would like to work with me to design and prototype a web app which fills this function, let me know.

-JamesFW

Olin College '15
https://github.com/jimmyfw



On Sat, Nov 30, 2013 at 11:53 PM, Max Novendstern <mnovendstern@gmail.com> wrote:
Great talk Jacob!

As an audience member, I would love more specific examples of what "closing a gestalt" looks like. And then -- just as important -- what happens once it's closed.

Some scattered thoughts:

- Is the notion of an "efficient market" directly applicable to, if not entirely comprehensive of, your goal? "A more efficient market for matching up people who [want to work on a given project]..."

- I want to pressure you to take seriously the limits of "awareness" as a solvent for social problems.

Take corruption in Congress. Many people are aware that Congressional Reps. spend 30%-70% of their time raising money from .05% the U.S. population. It's part of the reason Congress has less support today than the British Parliament did on the eve of the Revolution!

But greater "transparency" -- or better "markets" connecting passionate people with organizations -- is not obviously what's needed. Consider this: in the case of campaign finance reform, the facts can be distorting.

The casual reader -- your proverbial "bomb in Baghdad" news consumer -- might conclude that a congresswoman is corrupt because she took money from some group, or that she's not corrupt because she didn't take money from that group, when in truth, the nature of corruption in Congress is subtle and deep, far more complex than the casual reader would rationally want to spend their finite time comprehending.

In fact, this is a general principle: our active memories are finite. So the fewer things we're forced to fit into them, the more rational we can be about the things we want to think about. It's often said that a great trap of poverty is that so many fewer facts are "settled." It's doubly hard to take care of your family, or make to optimal career decisions, when you have to fill your active memory with issues about where you'll find food, whether the electricity is working, and how you're going to transport yourself from one place to another.

At best, food, electricity, and transportation "just work." The less you have to know, the better. And this is true of a host of social issues.

Here's my point. Corruption in Congress will be solved by institutional change. We'll change the laws. In the process, if more people know more things, that's great! It may be useful to the cause. But don't think it's intrinsically valuable. To the contrary, knowledge about everything cannot and should not be achieved. To say it more provocatively: keeping people ignorant (about things that will waste their finite active memories) is a great social good! In this specific sense, I'm pro ignorance.

Max

The casual reader -- your proverbial "bomb in Baghdad" news consumer -- might conclude that a congresswoman is corrupt because she took money from some group, or that she's not corrupt because she didn't take money from that group, when in truth, the nature of corruption in Congress is subtle and deep, far more complex than the casual reader would rationally want to spend their finite time comprehending.

In fact, this is a general principle: our active memories are finite. So the fewer things we're forced to fit into them, the more rational we can be about the things we want to think about. It's doubly hard to take care of your family, or make to optimal career decisions, when you have to fill your active memory with issues about where you'll find food, whether the electricity is working, and how you're going to transport yourself from one place to another.

At best, food, electricity, and transportation "just work." The less you have to know, the better. And this is true of a host of social issues.

Here's my point. Corruption in Congress will be solved by institutional change. We'll change the laws. In the process, if more people know more things, that's great! It may be useful to the cause. But don't think it's intrinsically valuable. To the contrary, knowledge about everything cannot and should not be achieved.
