subject: Fwd: We've got 72 hours to save SB 50
content:
The future of CA is in the balance. Do you want a California with housing
our generation could actually afford? Please join me in calling for a vote
for SB50 this year, the most important state legislation in the cards. It’s
been shot down undemocratically and it needs to move forward now.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Laura from YIMBY Action <hello@yimbyaction.org>
Date: Fri, May 17, 2019 at 10:44
Subject: We've got 72 hours to save SB 50
To: <me@omardiab.com>


This is your rallying call for More HOMES and other important housing bills.
Don't let this stand. Demand a Vote for SB 50!

Yesterday Senate Bill 50, the MoreHOMES Act, had a major setback
<https://yimbyaction.us15.list-manage.com/track/click?u=80dc2a6db6f9f02cf3a35eaf9&id=09cc660165&e=e1a5869b2d>.
This
bill has the potential to vastly increase home building near mass transit
and in single-family home neighborhoods across California - *and it ain't
over.*

Senate President pro tempore Toni Atkins has the power to save Senate Bill
50 and ensure a floor vote before the end of May. She'll only do that if
people demand it.

That's where you come in.
1) Ask Senator Atkins to bring SB 50 for a vote.

Tell her office that you want SB 50 to be voted on the floor of the State
Senate *this legislative session*.

Across the state, ask your friends to make this call. If you have a network
in* San Diego*, we especially hope they can call Senator Atkins.

*Senator Toni Atkins*
(916) 651-4039

*Optional Script: *
Hi, my name is _____. I’m calling because SB 50, the More HOMES Act, is
extremely important to me. I live in _____ and I'm tired of seeing how high
housing costs are damaging my community. It's time to bring the More HOMES
Act to the Senate floor. *We need a vote THIS YEAR.*
2) Express Yourself, using #MoreHOMESthisyear

Whether it's short tweet tagging @SenToniAtkins or a long medium post, ask
for a vote *this year* for SB 50. You can write a Facebook screed, a
Tweetstorm, a Nextdoor rant or share a long email to your elected
officials. Use the long list of endorsers from the SB 50 Fact Sheet
<https://yimbyaction.us15.list-manage.com/track/click?u=80dc2a6db6f9f02cf3a35eaf9&id=08750eb592&e=e1a5869b2d>
to
back up your case.

Find other people's pro-SB 50 comments and elevate them. *The drumbeat on
social media must be undeniable.* Tag @yimbyaction or email us your content
and we'll share them.
3) Keep the momentum going

*Forward this email to a friend.*
<http://us15.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=80dc2a6db6f9f02cf3a35eaf9&id=7f87ccce27&e=e1a5869b2d>

Add a preface about why this issue is so important to you personally. Tell
them now is the time. Because it is.
There are still more pro-housing bills to support.

No matter what happens with Senate Bill 50, there are still many local and
state issues that we'll continue to fight for. The next state bill priority
is Senate Bill 330, so take action now!

html_content:
The future of CA is in the balance. Do you want a California with housing our generation could actually afford? Please join me in calling for a vote for SB50 this year, the most important state legislation in the cards. It’s been shot down undemocratically and it needs to move forward now.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Laura from YIMBY Action <hello@yimbyaction.org>
Date: Fri, May 17, 2019 at 10:44
Subject: We've got 72 hours to save SB 50
To: <me@omardiab.com>


This is your rallying call for More HOMES and other important housing bills.

Don't let this stand.

Demand a Vote for SB 50!

Yesterday Senate Bill 50, the MoreHOMES Act, had a major setback. This bill has the potential to vastly increase home building near mass transit and in single-family home neighborhoods across California - and it ain't over.

Senate President pro tempore Toni Atkins has the power to save Senate Bill 50 and ensure a floor vote before the end of May. She'll only do that if people demand it.

That's where you come in.

1) Ask Senator Atkins to bring SB 50 for a vote.

Tell her office that you want SB 50 to be voted on the floor of the State Senate this legislative session. 

Across the state, ask your friends to make this call. If you have a network in San Diego, we especially hope they can call Senator Atkins.
 

Senator Toni Atkins
(916) 651-4039
 
Optional Script:
Hi, my name is _____. I’m calling because SB 50, the More HOMES Act, is extremely important to me. I live in _____ and I'm tired of seeing how high housing costs are damaging my community. It's time to bring the More HOMES Act to the Senate floor. We need a vote THIS YEAR.

2) Express Yourself, using #MoreHOMESthisyear

Whether it's short tweet tagging @SenToniAtkins or a long medium post, ask for a vote this year for SB 50. You can write a Facebook screed, a Tweetstorm, a Nextdoor rant or share a long email to your elected officials. Use the long list of endorsers from the SB 50 Fact Sheet to back up your case.

Find other people's pro-SB 50 comments and elevate them. The drumbeat on social media must be undeniable. Tag @yimbyaction or email us your content and we'll share them.

3) Keep the momentum going 
Forward this email to a friend.
 
Add a preface about why this issue is so important to you personally. Tell them now is the time. Because it is. 

There are still more pro-housing bills to support.

No matter what happens with Senate Bill 50, there are still many local and state issues that we'll continue to fight for. The next state bill priority is Senate Bill 330, so take action now!
Email Your Support for SB 330

On Tue, Nov 12, 2013 at 1:43 AM, Holden Lee <holdenlee@alum.mit.edu> wrote:
Timothy Gowers is leading a new collaborative research effort (polymath project) on the P vs. NP problem:
http://gowers.wordpress.com/2013/10/24/what-i-did-in-my-summer-holidays/
It's a long read, I've highlighted some important points: 
http://marker.to/wnY8PT 
(His "tiddlyspace" can be found here: http://gowers.tiddlyspace.com/#)
What's really interesting, and new in this project, is that he's making the whole process of mathematical research transparent through what he calls "proof discovery trees." It's apparent that so much more can be done if he had the websites that are especially designed for this kind of organization. 

Anyway, I'm throwing this out there in case people want ideas to work on, or know of good resources for this kind of thing.

(@Jacob: this meshes well with your IdeaOverflow idea; Gowers sets out a lot of features that would be useful from a research perspective.)

-Holden

subject: Polymath: Collaborative math research
content:
Timothy Gowers is leading a new collaborative research effort (polymath
project) on the P vs. NP problem:
http://gowers.wordpress.com/2013/10/24/what-i-did-in-my-summer-holidays/
It's a long read, I've highlighted some important points:
http://marker.to/wnY8PT  <http://marker.to/wnY8PT>
(His "tiddlyspace" can be found here: http://gowers.tiddlyspace.com/#)
What's really interesting, and new in this project, is that he's making the
whole process of mathematical research transparent through what he calls
"proof discovery trees." It's apparent that so much more can be done if he
had the websites that are especially designed for this kind of
organization.

Anyway, I'm throwing this out there in case people want ideas to work on,
or know of good resources for this kind of thing.

(@Jacob: this meshes well with your IdeaOverflow idea; Gowers sets out a
lot of features that would be useful from a research perspective.)

-Holden
html_content:
Timothy Gowers is leading a new collaborative research effort (polymath project) on the P vs. NP problem:
http://gowers.wordpress.com/2013/10/24/what-i-did-in-my-summer-holidays/
It's a long read, I've highlighted some important points: 
http://marker.to/wnY8PT 
(His "tiddlyspace" can be found here: http://gowers.tiddlyspace.com/#)
What's really interesting, and new in this project, is that he's making the whole process of mathematical research transparent through what he calls "proof discovery trees." It's apparent that so much more can be done if he had the websites that are especially designed for this kind of organization. 

Anyway, I'm throwing this out there in case people want ideas to work on, or know of good resources for this kind of thing.

(@Jacob: this meshes well with your IdeaOverflow idea; Gowers sets out a lot of features that would be useful from a research perspective.)

-Holden

A friend of mine is hosting an API mash-up hackathon this weekend.
See below for more info!

Dan


[image: HEADER]<http://mobext.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=435b10bbc7d6f2a07b7fd7fda&id=db719f2aca&e=83de566f8c>
We believe collective intelligence is the key to solving consumer
challenges.
So we're bringing people and platforms together for 48 hours on a live
brief to see just what can be achieved.
It might be frenzied. But it'll be fun. Food, drinks and live band included.
TASK
In 48 hours teams must create a working prototype using at least 2 of the
APIs from the platforms we provide. At the end of the deadline, each team
gets 5 minutes to present their idea to a panel of three judges. The best
idea wins.
PRIZE
$5,000
Plus a Paid opportunity to develop the prototype into a full range product.
TEAMS
Maximum of 4 people per team. Developers, Designers, Makers, Strategists,
or anyone who's up for the challenge are welcome.

subject: Opportunity to work with two of the world's best poker players
content:
Hey guys,

Two of my friends (Tom Dwan and Vivek Rajkumar) are two of the world's best
poker players and are very well connected in the casino industry. They are
working on a pretty cool idea and asked me to forward the following to
awesome people I know.

*There's a clear flaw in the taxi system model where there is no simple way
for a customer to give an opinion of their driver. Your customers are
autonomous, thinking, conscious, humans... And when possible you should try
to get a very quick snippet of their thoughts. Uber does this. Yelp does
this. In some industries it isn't worth as much.*

*At casinos I think it would be worth a significant amount. I believe it
should be fairly doable to have an RFID in every employees nametag, and an
app setup where you try to incentivize (likely by giving casino player
points) people to give their opinions on the employees they interact with.
The core idea is clearly aimed at a way smaller market than uber or yelp...
But it's also a market where you could end up with extremely accurate
ratings (which are worth more per 1opinion), and a casino employee who
messes up costs the company way more than your average bad cab driver costs
a cab company.*

Feel free to reach out to me if interested!

Best,
Prabhav Jain
html_content:
Hey guys, 

Two of my friends (Tom Dwan and Vivek Rajkumar) are two of the world's best poker players and are very well connected in the casino industry. They are working on a pretty cool idea and asked me to forward the following to awesome people I know.

There's a clear flaw in the taxi system model where there is no simple way for a customer to give an opinion of their driver. Your customers are autonomous, thinking, conscious, humans... And when possible you should try to get a very quick snippet of their thoughts. Uber does this. Yelp does this. In some industries it isn't worth as much.

At casinos I think it would be worth a significant amount. I believe it should be fairly doable to have an RFID in every employees nametag, and an app setup where you try to incentivize (likely by giving casino player points) people to give their opinions on the employees they interact with. The core idea is clearly aimed at a way smaller market than uber or yelp... But it's also a market where you could end up with extremely accurate ratings (which are worth more per 1opinion), and a casino employee who messes up costs the company way more than your average bad cab driver costs a cab company.

Feel free to reach out to me if interested!

Best,
Prabhav Jain

html_content:
My MIT jobs list posting!

On Sep 12, 2014 2:07 PM, "Jacob Cole" <jcole@mit.edu> wrote:

My MIT Jobslist posting!

Project: index.ideajoin.jacobcole.net

"Suggestion Graph" Demo: jcr.stcatz.ox.ac.uk/ideas/; see also Graph view (refresh page once after load if necessary). Platform has 2,000+ users and caused Oxford colleges to amend constitutions to require its use.

Seeking: a very special full-time (or thesis-level) collaborator, who is ideally either a hardcore web developer or hard-core NLP/ML programmer, ideally passionate about graphs and connecting ideas/people. Ideally in Boston or Bay Area. Might anyone be able to refer anyone?

Offering: Deeply meaningful work attempting to lay the groundwork for AI's that autonomously create ideas while creating a platform to connect people and their ideas. Can pay full-time salary if necessary + founder-level equity; investment offer from billionaire Nicolas Berggruen who is in Boston next week and wants to meet up in person with potential collaborators.

Contact: Jacob Cole <jcole@mit.edu>

Hi all, I'm Jacob Cole <jcole@mit.edu>, a course 6 (Electrical Eng. and Computer Science) senior.

Right now I see the most fundamental pressing problem in the world is that human activity is scattered. 

People with synergistic ideas in research groups, big companies, and society aren't aware of each other. (Prof. Tim Berners-Lee, who's been an adviser on this project, said in 2011 "There are millions of scientists trying to cure the likes of AIDS and Alzheimer's. Maybe the cure is currently separated in different people's heads. How can we design the web so that these half-formed solutions can come together? How can we build a really creative space for scientists?") At the same time, talented people start redundant or non-meaningful startups even when there are many low-hanging and relevant ideas available. Moreover, news media has a short attention span; we hear about bombings in Syria and earthquakes in Haiti one week and something else the next, even if the problems aren't resolved. As a result, the well-being of suffering people is at the mercy of what entertains the first world.

This isn't okay.

Prof. Minsky's Society of Mind concept teaches us that a mind is a system to meditate between a collection of little agents, and that society can be thought of as a mind. This mind is currently scatterbrained.

I'm working to solve this via a project at the intersection of semantic Web, UI, and AI, creating a platform to collaboratively build graphs of ideas <index.ideajoin.jacobcole.net>, that I started nearly 2 years ago in Prof. Marvin Minsky's Society of Mind class. This summer, the project got a funding offer <funding.ideajoin.jacobcole.net> from billionaire Nicolas Berggruen, who wants to use the platform for idea management within the companies he runs. We are seeking a very special full-time collaborator on the project. Nicolas will be in Boston next week and wants to meet up in person with potential collaborators.


An introduction to the paradigm: Building the Giant Global Graph of Ideas

One tip of the iceberg of the project is an attempt to create the best-ever software for keeping and sharing lists of ideas. This software will, critically, allow users to note relationships between ideas. This is powerful; consider: right now, people who hold the pieces to each other's puzzles pass in the hallway without knowing it. One person might have a relationship between idea A and idea B in his head, another person might have relation between idea B and idea C in her head, and when they talk, they end up with a shared graph A <> B <> C . As people  all over the world have conversations and note connections, a Giant Global Graph of ideas larger than that in any individual's head, is constructed, but, until now, not captured in a central place. Prof. Tim Berners-Lee, who's been my research adviser this past year, proposes the GGG as the next evolution of the Web, and cites Facebook as one of the first major sites to capitalize on a piece of the vision.

A human-machine hybrid system to suggest related ideas:
Manually intermeshing graphs of ideas is powerful alone, but becomes even more significant when facilitated by AI. Much of my research has consisted of developing NLP/ML algorithms, with the current version based on MIT ConceptNet, a graph of >16 million commonsense concepts and the relations between them, to automatically suggest related ideas which humans can approve or reject as actually related. This is a rough analogue of Facebook's "People you may know" feature for suggesting ideas. Incidentally, this creates a new paradigm for Internet research structurally better than Google for many types of investigation <researchlists.jacobcole.net>.

My longtime friend Malcom Gilbert, who is an experienced web developer, is planning to do his AI MEng thesis with Prof. Patrick Winston, on the topic of this project. There are several professors in support of this project who have potentially be thesis advisors. If you or anyone ideal you know would like to be involved on a lower time-commitment scale, like undergraduate research, we may be able to arrange that as well.

It would be transformatively helpful to the project I'm most passionate in my life if anyone might be able to help find the right additional collaborator.

^^



--
Jacob Cole
qoɔɐɾ

Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
jcole@mit.edu | (858) 740-6970

subject: Re: Logarithms
content:
Good call. Hmm well here's what e^(ln x) looks like in the new notation:

[image: Inline images 1]
To me that looks somewhat intuitive - like "oh so you go both up and down
in base e, that makes sense that it evaluates to x." Maybe I'm imagining
that though.

You can continue this and do nested things as well:

[image: Inline images 2]
Again, you can see that the surrounding e's drop out.

I'm not sure about the plaintext problem, though. Perhaps with Unicode you
could do it?


On 9 May 2014 16:24, Nimish Pratha <nimish.pratha@gmail.com> wrote:

> not to be a debbie downer but there are other problems with the system.
>
> i agree that it serves well as an immediately recognizable visual
> counterpart to the exponent. however, stacking logs in exponent expressions
> with this system becomes problematic and, personally, ugly.
>
> consider e^(ln x). you see this all the time. under this system it would
> be e^(e^x) (?). herein we have two problems. one, there's no steady
> rightward progression; in terms of character size, the expression is
> ordered 1 3 2, with 1 being the largest. two, how exactly are we to encode
> this new expression system in plain text? the introduction of this makes
> the ^ relation ambiguous. is e^x e to the x, or ln x?
>
>

html_content:
Good call. Hmm well here's what e^(ln x) looks like in the new notation:


To me that looks somewhat intuitive - like "oh so you go both up and down in base e, that makes sense that it evaluates to x." Maybe I'm imagining that though.

You can continue this and do nested things as well: 

Again, you can see that the surrounding e's drop out.  

I'm not sure about the plaintext problem, though. Perhaps with Unicode you could do it?


On 9 May 2014 16:24, Nimish Pratha <nimish.pratha@gmail.com> wrote:
not to be a debbie downer but there are other problems with the system.

i agree that it serves well as an immediately recognizable visual counterpart to the exponent. however, stacking logs in exponent expressions with this system becomes problematic and, personally, ugly.

consider e^(ln x). you see this all the time. under this system it would be e^(e^x) (?). herein we have two problems. one, there's no steady rightward progression; in terms of character size, the expression is ordered 1 3 2, with 1 being the largest. two, how exactly are we to encode this new expression system in plain text? the introduction of this makes the ^ relation ambiguous. is e^x e to the x, or ln x? 


On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 4:14 PM, H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetration

Best Regards,
Howon Lee

subject: Re: Logarithms
content:
Nimish, this isn't a real problem. Left super scripts are a already a
widely used thing.
The plaintext notation \LaTeX uses works well enough: ^{ls}X^{rs}
Use braces where ambiguous.

The concerns thus far raised are integration implementation details.

More important is to figure out what power this new notation affords.

subject: Re: Logarithms
content:
not to be a debbie downer but there are other problems with the system.

i agree that it serves well as an immediately recognizable visual
counterpart to the exponent. however, stacking logs in exponent expressions
with this system becomes problematic and, personally, ugly.

consider e^(ln x). you see this all the time. under this system it would be
e^(e^x) (?). herein we have two problems. one, there's no steady rightward
progression; in terms of character size, the expression is ordered 1 3 2,
with 1 being the largest. two, how exactly are we to encode this new
expression system in plain text? the introduction of this makes the ^
relation ambiguous. is e^x e to the x, or ln x?

html_content:
not to be a debbie downer but there are other problems with the system.

i agree that it serves well as an immediately recognizable visual counterpart to the exponent. however, stacking logs in exponent expressions with this system becomes problematic and, personally, ugly.

consider e^(ln x). you see this all the time. under this system it would be e^(e^x) (?). herein we have two problems. one, there's no steady rightward progression; in terms of character size, the expression is ordered 1 3 2, with 1 being the largest. two, how exactly are we to encode this new expression system in plain text? the introduction of this makes the ^ relation ambiguous. is e^x e to the x, or ln x?

On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 3:55 PM, David Furlong <david.furlong@stcatz.ox.ac.uk> wrote:

Elaina’s use is much much better than the current uses outlined on stack exchange. 
I especially like the way the product rule for logs now comes naturally from the rule for multiplying polynomials with the same base.
This needs to become the standard!  (Although it may mean more bracketing due to more frequent ambiguous expressions)

Regards,

David

I tried re-imagining logarithms as being a left hand exponent and made a table of some common things. It feels a bit more clear to me (especially in that it's closely tied to exponentials), but perhaps not. The power rule is the most confusing in the new notation (but not more so than it usually looks perhaps?). What do you think?

On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 3:55 PM, David Furlong <david.furlong@stcatz.ox.ac.uk> wrote:

Elaina’s use is much much better than the current uses outlined on stack exchange. 
I especially like the way the product rule for logs now comes naturally from the rule for multiplying polynomials with the same base.
This needs to become the standard!  (Although it may mean more bracketing due to more frequent ambiguous expressions)

Regards,

David

I tried re-imagining logarithms as being a left hand exponent and made a table of some common things. It feels a bit more clear to me (especially in that it's closely tied to exponentials), but perhaps not. The power rule is the most confusing in the new notation (but not more so than it usually looks perhaps?). What do you think?

subject: Re: Logarithms
content:
Yeah, this is mostly me being a curmudgeon. But there would also be
considerable logistical difficulties (eg., previous hundreds of years of
momentum in logarithm notation) in getting people to actually adopt the
notation, and that seems like 96% of the difficulty with adoption.

Best Regards,
Howon Lee

subject: Re: Universal AI and a Formal Theory of Fun
content:
Random facts, thanks to synchronicity:

The most common phrases for laugh-inducing in human interaction:

1. "I know"
2. "I'll see you guys later"
3. "I see your point"
4. "It was nice meeting you"

R. Provine notes that laughter and humor are not correlated

Best,
Howon Lee

subject:
Re: [OGM] Neural networks vs. Neocortical processes (was: Noam
 Chomsky: The False Promise of ChatGPT)
content:
#2 and #3 should be addressed by multimodality and embodiment in robots at
least. Agreed that LLMs are still a long ways away from exhibiting
intelligence. GPT-4 seems like a good step!

On Tue, Mar 21, 2023 at 3:18 AM Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

> Interesting thread— would love to discuss!
>
> ---------- Forwarded message ---------
> From: Jacob Cole <jacob@ideaflow.io>
> Date: Tue, Mar 21, 2023 at 12:16 AM
> Subject: Fwd: [OGM] Neural networks vs. Neocortical processes (was: Noam
> Chomsky: The False Promise of ChatGPT)
> To: Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com>
>
>
>
>
> ---------- Forwarded message ---------
> From: Peter Kaminski <kaminski@istori.com>
> Date: Fri, Mar 17, 2023 at 7:45 AM
> Subject: [OGM] Neural networks vs. Neocortical processes (was: Noam
> Chomsky: The False Promise of ChatGPT)
> To: Ken Homer <kenhomer@sonic.net>, Jerry Michalski <sociate@gmail.com>,
> Open Global Mind <openglobalmind@googlegroups.com>
>
>
> > [Hawkins] does make the point that most neural nets are not based on the
> way the human brain processes information and ultimately will fail as AIs
> unless they make some major changes.
> >
> > Maybe Pete can give a better accounting of that part of his book, Pete,
> are you up for that challenge?
>
> Sure thing, Ken. And thank you for turning me onto, and helping me get
> into, his "Thousand Brains" book.
>
> For me, it's been sort of an extension of the story I originally learned
> via neurophysiologist William Calvin and his "How Brains Think" books:
>
> - How Brains Think, http://williamcalvin.com/bk8/
> - Cerebral Code, http://williamcalvin.com/bk9/
>
> Calvin was where I first heard of cortical columns. Where Hawkins
> describes "voting" between cortical columns, Calvin describes something
> similar, but likens the proceeding of the vote sort of like a choir
> recruiting new voices, or as a Darwinian process between concepts, played
> out over the population of cortical columns.
>
> Hawkins' explanation of how brains think has more components than just
> voting, because he's 25-30 years farther along in research than Calvin's
> work from the mid-90's.
>
> Anyway, artificial neural networks were inspired by the way biological
> neurons work, but they're simplified models of real neurons.
>
> And even though current AIs use many, many neurons, they're still not
> arranged to form cortical columns, etc., and they're not used in the same
> way a real brain with a neocortex uses neurons.
>
> Please take the following with a grain of salt; I'm not a
> neurophysiologist, and this is just my poor understanding from reading
> Hawkins and Calvin.  I may have important parts over-simplified, or even
> wrong.
>
> Cortical columns are semi-autonomous "sensory-motor" brain structures
> formed of several tens of thousands of neurons. Each cortical column
> develops "models" of the outside world from the sensory inputs it receives
> (some get input from vision, some from touch, some from hearing, etc.), and
> can model hundreds of different things.
>
> The models include a "reference frame".  You can think of a reference
> frame as something like the grid system in a paper map, although reference
> frames are not limited to two dimensions; they might have just one
> dimension, or more than two, more than three, etc.
>
> As a human moves through physical or conceptual space, sensory inputs to
> the ~150,000 cortical columns change, and all the cortical columns do
> parallel "predictions" of what sensory inputs will come next, based on
> their reading of their models and reference maps.  When sensory input and
> the predictions don't match, that is "learning".
>
> Hawkins' observes that current AIs are typically pre-trained, and have a
> simplified single task, of say, recognizing what image inputs correspond to
> what object, due to similarities and differences learned in training and
> then observed in a particular image.
>
> In the "thousand brains" model, though, there are many -- possibly
> thousands -- of interlocking models, that assess sensory input not just in
> one mode (say, vision), but in multiple modes simultaneously.  The cortical
> columns cooperate in a "vote" to develop, in your brain, a consensus
> understanding of what they're perceiving.
>
> The key hallmarks of real intelligence for Hawkins (p. 149 et seq.) are:
>
> 1. Learning continuously. Not pre-trained; literally learning with every
> movement. Hawkins writes, "The most important component of how brains learn
> continuously is the neuron. When a neuron learns a new pattern, it forms
> new synapses on one dendrite branch. The new synapses don't affect
> previously learned ones on other branches. Thus, learning something new
> doesn't force the neuron to forget or modify something it learned earlier.
> The artificial neurons used in today's AI systems don't have this ability.
> This is one reason they can't learn continuously."
>
> 2. Learning via movement. "We cannot sense everything in the world at
> once; therefore, movement is required for learning."  (By "movement" here,
> Hawkins means both actual physical movement, and conceptual movement, such
> as moving through a sequence of notes in a song, or reading a list of
> democratic principles.)
>
> 3. Many models, as described above. "Knowledge about any particular thing,
> such as a coffee cup,
> is distributed among many complementary models." (What it looks like, what
> it feels like when you touch it in different ways, how the the way it looks
> different when you pick it up and move it around to different angles, what
> you've observed happen when you turn it upside down when there's liquid in
> it, etc., etc.)
>
> 4. Using reference frames to store knowledge. "Most artificial neural
> networks have nothing equivalent to reference frames. For example, a
> typical neural network that recognizes images just assigns a label to each
> image. Without reference frames, the network has no way of learning the 3D
> structure of objects or how they move and change. One of the problems with
> a system like this is that we can't ask why it labeled something a cat. The

> 'cat.'"
>
> Hawkins writes about his list of attributes: "My proposal for what
> qualifies as intelligent is based on the brain. Each of the four attributes
> in the following list is something we know that the brain does and that I

> choice of attributes. One can make a good argument that I have left some

> for AGI. Few AI systems have any of these attributes today."
>
> I recommend reading the whole book, not just this short summary. Hawkins'

On Tue, Mar 21, 2023 at 3:18 AM Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:
Interesting thread— would love to discuss!

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Jacob Cole <jacob@ideaflow.io>
Date: Tue, Mar 21, 2023 at 12:16 AM
Subject: Fwd: [OGM] Neural networks vs. Neocortical processes (was: Noam Chomsky: The False Promise of ChatGPT)
To: Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com>




---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Peter Kaminski <kaminski@istori.com>
Date: Fri, Mar 17, 2023 at 7:45 AM
Subject: [OGM] Neural networks vs. Neocortical processes (was: Noam Chomsky: The False Promise of ChatGPT)
To: Ken Homer <kenhomer@sonic.net>, Jerry Michalski <sociate@gmail.com>, Open Global Mind <openglobalmind@googlegroups.com>


> [Hawkins] does make the point that most neural nets are not based on the way the human brain processes information and ultimately will fail as AIs unless they make some major changes.
>
> Maybe Pete can give a better accounting of that part of his book, Pete, are you up for that challenge?

Sure thing, Ken. And thank you for turning me onto, and helping me get into, his "Thousand Brains" book.

For me, it's been sort of an extension of the story I originally learned via neurophysiologist William Calvin and his "How Brains Think" books:

- How Brains Think, http://williamcalvin.com/bk8/
- Cerebral Code, http://williamcalvin.com/bk9/

Calvin was where I first heard of cortical columns. Where Hawkins describes "voting" between cortical columns, Calvin describes something similar, but likens the proceeding of the vote sort of like a choir recruiting new voices, or as a Darwinian process between concepts, played out over the population of cortical columns.

Hawkins' explanation of how brains think has more components than just voting, because he's 25-30 years farther along in research than Calvin's work from the mid-90's.

Anyway, artificial neural networks were inspired by the way biological neurons work, but they're simplified models of real neurons.

And even though current AIs use many, many neurons, they're still not arranged to form cortical columns, etc., and they're not used in the same way a real brain with a neocortex uses neurons.

Please take the following with a grain of salt; I'm not a neurophysiologist, and this is just my poor understanding from reading Hawkins and Calvin.  I may have important parts over-simplified, or even wrong.

Cortical columns are semi-autonomous "sensory-motor" brain structures formed of several tens of thousands of neurons. Each cortical column develops "models" of the outside world from the sensory inputs it receives (some get input from vision, some from touch, some from hearing, etc.), and can model hundreds of different things.

The models include a "reference frame".  You can think of a reference frame as something like the grid system in a paper map, although reference frames are not limited to two dimensions; they might have just one dimension, or more than two, more than three, etc.

As a human moves through physical or conceptual space, sensory inputs to the ~150,000 cortical columns change, and all the cortical columns do parallel "predictions" of what sensory inputs will come next, based on their reading of their models and reference maps.  When sensory input and the predictions don't match, that is "learning".

Hawkins' observes that current AIs are typically pre-trained, and have a simplified single task, of say, recognizing what image inputs correspond to what object, due to similarities and differences learned in training and then observed in a particular image.

In the "thousand brains" model, though, there are many -- possibly thousands -- of interlocking models, that assess sensory input not just in one mode (say, vision), but in multiple modes simultaneously.  The cortical columns cooperate in a "vote" to develop, in your brain, a consensus understanding of what they're perceiving.

The key hallmarks of real intelligence for Hawkins (p. 149 et seq.) are:

1. Learning continuously. Not pre-trained; literally learning with every movement. Hawkins writes, "The most important component of how brains learn continuously is the neuron. When a neuron learns a new pattern, it forms new synapses on one dendrite branch. The new synapses don't affect previously learned ones on other branches. Thus, learning something new doesn't force the neuron to forget or modify something it learned earlier. The artificial neurons used in today's AI systems don't have this ability. This is one reason they can't learn continuously."

2. Learning via movement. "We cannot sense everything in the world at once; therefore, movement is required for learning."  (By "movement" here, Hawkins means both actual physical movement, and conceptual movement, such as moving through a sequence of notes in a song, or reading a list of democratic principles.)

3. Many models, as described above. "Knowledge about any particular thing, such as a coffee cup,
is distributed among many complementary models." (What it looks like, what it feels like when you touch it in different ways, how the the way it looks different when you pick it up and move it around to different angles, what you've observed happen when you turn it upside down when there's liquid in it, etc., etc.)

4. Using reference frames to store knowledge. "Most artificial neural networks have nothing equivalent to reference frames. For example, a typical neural network that recognizes images just assigns a label to each image. Without reference frames, the network has no way of learning the 3D structure of objects or how they move and change. One of the problems with a system like this is that we can't ask why it labeled something a cat. The AI system doesn't know what a cat is. There is no further information to be had, beyond that this image is similar to other images that were labeled 'cat.'"

Hawkins writes about his list of attributes: "My proposal for what qualifies as intelligent is based on the brain. Each of the four attributes in the following list is something we know that the brain does and that I believe an
intelligent machine [AGI] must do too. Not everyone will agree with my choice of attributes. One can make a good argument that I have left some important things out. That's OK. I view my list as a minimum, or baseline, for AGI. Few AI systems have any of these attributes today."

I recommend reading the whole book, not just this short summary. Hawkins' book does a good job of making the topic much more clear. But hopefully this gives you a taste of the difference Hawkins draws between current AI and real intelligence.

Pete

subject: Getting Services from Friends of Friends
content:
This is a really powerful paradigm (my personal fav application is social
ridesharing).

I bring it up because my exuberant friend Jacob Ong just got a chunk of
funding to expand his platform for enabling this, errund.com, and wanted to
know if anyone was interested in joining his team or synergizing with him.
Know anybody who might be?

-- 
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970

subject: Re: Ideas for Advertising Kickstarter Project
content:
Makerfaires often work as okay advertising, people sell their random
gadgets and printers there.

Try to get articles written about your gadget? Do a giveaway promo with
Engadget or someone else, to get on people's "tech radar".

You could also try selling it as a magic phone case that both protects and
powers. On your kickstarter, the blurb about protecting your phone and
ejecting  is not as compelling as it should be, and it feels out of place.
A bit like an addition, not a well thought feature. You're selling to Apple
consumers, so you should take on the apple branding that this is a magic
lifestyle choice case that rescues you from the tyranny of lightening ports
and cracked screens with a fashionable sleek blue case that acts as the
Guardian angel of your phone. With chamfers.
Okay maybe not that far but consumers are expecting a polished apple
product for their apple product, and displaying that through cohesive
design is important.

Hope that was helpful,

Rebecca
html_content:
Makerfaires often work as okay advertising, people sell their random gadgets and printers there.

Try to get articles written about your gadget? Do a giveaway promo with Engadget or someone else, to get on people's "tech radar".

You could also try selling it as a magic phone case that both protects and powers. On your kickstarter, the blurb about protecting your phone and ejecting  is not as compelling as it should be, and it feels out of place. A bit like an addition, not a well thought feature. You're selling to Apple consumers, so you should take on the apple branding that this is a magic lifestyle choice case that rescues you from the tyranny of lightening ports and cracked screens with a fashionable sleek blue case that acts as the Guardian angel of your phone. With chamfers.
Okay maybe not that far but consumers are expecting a polished apple product for their apple product, and displaying that through cohesive design is important.

Hope that was helpful,

Rebecca

subject: Ideas for Advertising Kickstarter Project
content:
Hey guys,

I made CoBattery, an iPhone battery case that eliminates the need to plug
in your phone. We launched on Kickstarter with a goal of $60k and we are
about halfway through our time and halfway to our goal. You can check it
out here:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/cobattery/cobattery-never-plug-in-your-iphone-again

I was wondering if you guys had any ideas on advertising or have experience
advertising a product in the past. The Kickstarter started out fast but it
feels like we've sort of exhausted a lot of our personal circles and it's
getting hard to get it out to more people... We've tried business cards,
stickers, reaching out to media, and sending out to mailing lists.

I'd love to hear any creative ideas you guys have! Or if you have any
feedback on the project, would love to hear that too. :)

Best.

--
VPontis

Check out what I've been working on at CoBattery.com

I was wondering if you guys had any ideas on advertising or have experience advertising a product in the past. The Kickstarter started out fast but it feels like we've sort of exhausted a lot of our personal circles and it's getting hard to get it out to more people... We've tried business cards, stickers, reaching out to media, and sending out to mailing lists.

I'd love to hear any creative ideas you guys have! Or if you have any feedback on the project, would love to hear that too. :)

Best.

subject: Re: There is a need for a Hacksphere>jobs list I think
content:
I believe the folks on csail-related have this same conversation every
few years, and no one has yet found an ideal solution. Separate
sub-lists forked from an active main list rarely pick up enough
traffic to become self-sustaining, large groups of people can't be
relied on to use clever email tricks like +tags consistently,
especially in autocompleting interfaces that guide them back to the
main address, mixing jobs posts in with everything else can really
annoy people who actively avoid job posts . . . virtual communities
are complicated. Having moderated a mailing list myself for a while
and observed similar issues firsthand, I'm actually still optimistic
that software can eventually solve this problem, but perhaps not
immediately.

Zak

On Tue, Sep 9, 2014 at 3:29 PM, Max Song <maxsong123@gmail.com> wrote:
Whoa. 

Karl Rove is considered by many to be the strategist mastermind of the republican party. One issue of late has been the increasing dominance of the Tea-Party, and Karl Rove's initiative to create a SuperPAC to combat this influence. 

John Stewart covers it well here. 

“It’s as though the entire misguided shutdown affair was a culmination of a decade-long strategy to rile up and politically engage the most rigid and ideological pockets of the Republican party,” Stewart posited. 

The irony is that Rove himself may have been behind the inception of the Tea Party, outlined in the book Building Red America. 

As proof, Stewart cited Rove telling author Thomas Edsall in 2004 that Republicans were out to play to conservative voters’ “anger points” like marriage equality or “free health care for immigrants.”

Of course, such a question should probably be framed along the lines of "How do you interpret the rise to power of the Tea Party - what does their influence mean on the Republican Party?", to replace the edge of ad hominem for curiosity.

Anyone have any questions or ideas that would like to be answered by Karl Rove?

Pothana G. Kambhampati

On Wednesday, October 2, 2013, Daniel Windham wrote:
In the spirit of raising objections, then, mailing list proliferation is usually confounding. Some motivating examples:
  • I post about something cool a friend is working on, and propose a question about it. Meanwhile, the company is hiring, so I mention that, too. Under a segregated system, it's not clear where I post it: main? jobs? main + jobs at the same time? split it into separate messages, and reference each in the other?
  • I manage the lists under a segregated system. Do I correct people if they post to the wrong list? Do I repost it to the correct list?
  • I don't want to hear about +jobs, so I don't follow that list. When someone posts about a job to a list I do follow, do I have the prerogative to complain?
If you guys are excited about it, I say charge on. I will be the curious skeptic watching from the corner; and if necessary we can revert.

Daniel

subject: Re: There is a need for a Hacksphere>jobs list I think
content:
In the spirit of raising objections, then, mailing list proliferation is
usually confounding. Some motivating examples:

   - I post about something cool a friend is working on, and propose a
   question about it. Meanwhile, the company is hiring, so I mention that,
   too. Under a segregated system, it's not clear where I post it: main? jobs?
   main + jobs at the same time? split it into separate messages, and
   reference each in the other?
   - I manage the lists under a segregated system. Do I correct people if
   they post to the wrong list? Do I repost it to the correct list?
   - I don't want to hear about +jobs, so I don't follow that list. When
   someone posts about a job to a list I do follow, do I have the prerogative
   to complain?

If you guys are excited about it, I say charge on. I will be the curious
skeptic watching from the corner; and if necessary we can revert.

html_content:
In the spirit of raising objections, then, mailing list proliferation is usually confounding. Some motivating examples:
  • I post about something cool a friend is working on, and propose a question about it. Meanwhile, the company is hiring, so I mention that, too. Under a segregated system, it's not clear where I post it: main? jobs? main + jobs at the same time? split it into separate messages, and reference each in the other?
  • I manage the lists under a segregated system. Do I correct people if they post to the wrong list? Do I repost it to the correct list?
  • I don't want to hear about +jobs, so I don't follow that list. When someone posts about a job to a list I do follow, do I have the prerogative to complain?
If you guys are excited about it, I say charge on. I will be the curious skeptic watching from the corner; and if necessary we can revert.

Daniel

subject: Re: Questions for Former Presidential Adviser Karl Rove
content:
Whoa.

Karl Rove is considered by many to be the strategist mastermind of the
republican party. One issue of late has been the increasing dominance of
the Tea-Party, and Karl Rove's initiative to create a SuperPAC to combat
this influence.

John Stewart covers it well here
<http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2013/10/23/stewart-mocks-turd-blossom-karl-rove-for-having-to-battle-the-stupid-tea-party-he-unleashed/>
.

“*It’s as though the entire misguided shutdown affair was a culmination of
a decade-long strategy to rile up and politically engage the most rigid and
ideological pockets of the Republican party,” Stewart posited. *

The irony is that Rove himself may have been behind the inception of the
Tea Party, outlined in the book Building Red America
<http://www.amazon.com/Building-Red-America-Conservative-Coalition/dp/0465018165>
.

*As proof, Stewart cited Rove telling author Thomas Edsall in 2004
<http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/12/books/12kaku.html?pagewanted=all> that
Republicans were out to play to conservative voters’ “anger points” like
marriage equality or “free health care for immigrants.”*

Of course, such a question should probably be framed along the lines of *"How
do you interpret the rise to power of the Tea Party - what does their
influence mean on the Republican Party?", *to replace the edge of ad
hominem for curiosity.


On Tue, Sep 9, 2014 at 2:38 PM, Pothana Kambhampati <
someone.iknowwhoyouare@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hey all,
> Long time lurker and I know this doesn't pertain exactly to the hacksphere
> realm, but...
>
> A friend of mine is getting the chance to meet Karl Rove, senior adviser
> to George W. Bush, and will be taking a few questions regarding political
> issues or anything else in general.
>
> Anyone have any questions or ideas that would like to be answered by Karl
> Rove?
>
> --
> Thanks,
> Pothana G. Kambhampati
>
> --
> You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups
> "HackSphere" group.
> To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an
> email to HackSphere+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.
> For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.
>



-- 
"What is to give light must endure the burning."
--Frankl, Victor E.
html_content:
Whoa. 

Karl Rove is considered by many to be the strategist mastermind of the republican party. One issue of late has been the increasing dominance of the Tea-Party, and Karl Rove's initiative to create a SuperPAC to combat this influence. 

John Stewart covers it well here. 

“It’s as though the entire misguided shutdown affair was a culmination of a decade-long strategy to rile up and politically engage the most rigid and ideological pockets of the Republican party,” Stewart posited. 

The irony is that Rove himself may have been behind the inception of the Tea Party, outlined in the book Building Red America. 

As proof, Stewart cited Rove telling author Thomas Edsall in 2004 that Republicans were out to play to conservative voters’ “anger points” like marriage equality or “free health care for immigrants.”

Of course, such a question should probably be framed along the lines of "How do you interpret the rise to power of the Tea Party - what does their influence mean on the Republican Party?", to replace the edge of ad hominem for curiosity.

subject: Re: Net-positive energy Fusion power in 4 years? #Energy #Cool
content:
A notable book made the argument that our civilization stunted its growth when we failed to switch our society's power source to fission power, due to perception and regulatory issues. I think there's some truth to that perspective, and we might now struggle to jump to fusion power given that we lack widespread use of fission power.

— Raf

subject: Re: Automated theorem proving is like building robots
content:
*how far you can take your system
On Nov 14, 2014 12:07 PM, "Jacob Cole" <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

> If, as Holden Lee says, "math is exploring how far you can get from the
> foundation of absolute truth", then engineering research is exploring how
> far your system can take your system and still have it work.
>
> Both are about taking observations the logical extreme of their
> implications which we are motivated to do because if we are motivated to
> take the first step of an exploration, then why should that motivation not
> persist to drive us to take the second?
>
html_content:
*how far you can take your system

On Nov 14, 2014 12:07 PM, "Jacob Cole" <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

If, as Holden Lee says, "math is exploring how far you can get from the foundation of absolute truth", then engineering research is exploring how far your system can take your system and still have it work.

Both are about taking observations the logical extreme of their implications which we are motivated to do because if we are motivated to take the first step of an exploration, then why should that motivation not persist to drive us to take the second?

subject: Automated theorem proving is like building robots
content:
If, as Holden Lee says, "math is exploring how far you can get from the
foundation of absolute truth", then engineering research is exploring how
far your system can take your system and still have it work.

Both are about taking observations the logical extreme of their
implications which we are motivated to do because if we are motivated to
take the first step of an exploration, then why should that motivation not
persist to drive us to take the second?
html_content:
If, as Holden Lee says, "math is exploring how far you can get from the foundation of absolute truth", then engineering research is exploring how far your system can take your system and still have it work.

Both are about taking observations the logical extreme of their implications which we are motivated to do because if we are motivated to take the first step of an exploration, then why should that motivation not persist to drive us to take the second?

subject: Side effects of Glib
content:
A while ago I downloaded the Glib and GTK libraries because I thought I 
wanted to try my hand at developing applications in C.
I never did get around to actually using the libraries and I have since 
partially removed them from my hard drive.
However, ever since I built the libraries on my Ubuntu OS, I have been 
getting these weird debugging messages in my terminal every time I run 
programs from the command line.

When I run Chrome I get a lot of this guy:
[2060:2060:0626/001609:ERROR:omnibox_view_gtk.cc(431)] Not implemented 
reached in virtual void OmniboxViewGtk::ApplyCaretVisibility()

And whenever I run Sublime I get a lot of this guy:
GLib-GIO-Message: Using the 'memory' GSettings backend.  Your settings will 
not be saved or shared with other applications.

These messages, although interesting (as they provide some insight on what 
is going on in my OS), are beginning to overstay their welcome.
Anybody have experience with glib or C programming know how to turn this 
debugging output off?
html_content:
A while ago I downloaded the Glib and GTK libraries because I thought I wanted to try my hand at developing applications in C.
I never did get around to actually using the libraries and I have since partially removed them from my hard drive.
However, ever since I built the libraries on my Ubuntu OS, I have been getting these weird debugging messages in my terminal every time I run programs from the command line.

When I run Chrome I get a lot of this guy:
[2060:2060:0626/001609:ERROR:omnibox_view_gtk.cc(431)] Not implemented reached in virtual void OmniboxViewGtk::ApplyCaretVisibility()

And whenever I run Sublime I get a lot of this guy:
GLib-GIO-Message: Using the 'memory' GSettings backend.  Your settings will not be saved or shared with other applications.

These messages, although interesting (as they provide some insight on what is going on in my OS), are beginning to overstay their welcome.
Anybody have experience with glib or C programming know how to turn this debugging output off?

Ah this was done in the context of desktop apps few years ago by morgan dixon when he was a PhD student, his system is called https://prefab.github.io/  Prefab https://digital.lib.washington.edu/researchworks/bitstream/handle/1773/33702/Dixon_washington_0250E_14470.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y

You can also implement the same technique on Android (it lets you paint over screens and monitor what's onscreen via the accessibility APIs), in fact the android version of habitlab https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.stanfordhci.habitlab does this to some extent.

ᐧ

2017-10-20 18:28 GMT-07:00 Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com>:
I would want it to be systemwide. This is something that I have previously called "augmented virtuality" and Kevin Kwok called "augmented reality for framebuffers"

There are a ton of awesome things you could do with this.

I wonder if my friend Geza, who works on a completely awesome program called habitlab https://habitlab.stanford.edu/ which sits between you and your addictive apps/websites does things like swap out Facebook with duolingo if you're on it too long, might actually have some ideas here.

As a side comment: there's something that terrifies me about the locked down nature of iPhones -- they prevent you from messing with the basic experience with using the device. This seems contrary to the message of apples famous 1984 ad, which champions the potential of computers as a way to empower people instead of empowering corporate overlords to control people.

html_content:
Ah this was done in the context of desktop apps few years ago by morgan dixon when he was a PhD student, his system is called https://prefab.github.io/  Prefab https://digital.lib.washington.edu/researchworks/bitstream/handle/1773/33702/Dixon_washington_0250E_14470.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y

You can also implement the same technique on Android (it lets you paint over screens and monitor what's onscreen via the accessibility APIs), in fact the android version of habitlab https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.stanfordhci.habitlab does this to some extent.

ᐧ

2017-10-20 18:28 GMT-07:00 Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com>:
I would want it to be systemwide. This is something that I have previously called "augmented virtuality" and Kevin Kwok called "augmented reality for framebuffers"

There are a ton of awesome things you could do with this.

I wonder if my friend Geza, who works on a completely awesome program called habitlab https://habitlab.stanford.edu/ which sits between you and your addictive apps/websites does things like swap out Facebook with duolingo if you're on it too long, might actually have some ideas here.

As a side comment: there's something that terrifies me about the locked down nature of iPhones -- they prevent you from messing with the basic experience with using the device. This seems contrary to the message of apples famous 1984 ad, which champions the potential of computers as a way to empower people instead of empowering corporate overlords to control people.

subject: Re: How would I build a layer that sits between me and my computer?
content:
Atlas Recall is also worth checking out as it was kind of an API for APIs with the goal of “index[ing] all your information across many services", however they decided to call it quits after only a year. Perhaps due to the uneasiness of having a company be able to process everything you do on a digital device.

https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/18/atlas-informatics-calls-it-quits-after-less-than-a-year/

On Fri, Oct 20, 2017 at 6:44 PM, Andrey Fedorov <me@anfedorov.com> wrote:
On Mac, AppleScript is supposed to be a pretty powerful platform for what you're talking about, although I don't know how seriously macOS developers take their APIs for integrating with it. I imagine Keyboard Maestro is written in Objective-C, but would probably be better rewritten in Swift. It's probably more about knowing which API's to call rather than which language to use.

Windows has an accessibility layer which can serve for UI automation — a friend who integrated with it tells me it's pretty horrible — like interacting with a badly structured DOM, although it probably depends on the app.

Not sure about Android / iOS functionality & limitations, but agree the irony of 1984 ad is real. But back then Apple was tiny and IBM was huge. They would probably argue that if you want to make it better, you should go work for Apple ;)

subject: Re: How would I build a layer that sits between me and my computer?
content:
On Mac, AppleScript <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AppleScript> is supposed
to be a pretty powerful platform for what you're talking about, although I
don't know how seriously macOS developers take their APIs for integrating
with it. I imagine Keyboard Maestro is written in Objective-C, but would
probably be better rewritten in Swift. It's probably more about knowing
which API's to call rather than which language to use.

Windows has an accessibility layer which can serve for UI automation — a
friend who integrated with it tells me it's pretty horrible — like
interacting with a badly structured DOM, although it probably depends on
the app.

Not sure about Android / iOS functionality & limitations, but agree the
irony of 1984 ad is real. But back then Apple was tiny and IBM was huge.
They would probably argue that if you want to make it better, you should go
work for Apple ;)

On Mac, AppleScript is supposed to be a pretty powerful platform for what you're talking about, although I don't know how seriously macOS developers take their APIs for integrating with it. I imagine Keyboard Maestro is written in Objective-C, but would probably be better rewritten in Swift. It's probably more about knowing which API's to call rather than which language to use.

Windows has an accessibility layer which can serve for UI automation — a friend who integrated with it tells me it's pretty horrible — like interacting with a badly structured DOM, although it probably depends on the app.

Not sure about Android / iOS functionality & limitations, but agree the irony of 1984 ad is real. But back then Apple was tiny and IBM was huge. They would probably argue that if you want to make it better, you should go work for Apple ;)

subject: Re: How would I build a layer that sits between me and my computer?
content:
I would want it to be systemwide. This is something that I have previously
called "augmented virtuality" and Kevin Kwok called "augmented reality for
framebuffers"

There are a ton of awesome things you could do with this.

I wonder if my friend Geza, who works on a completely awesome program
called habitlab https://habitlab.stanford.edu/ which sits between you and
your addictive apps/websites does things like swap out Facebook with
duolingo if you're on it too long, might actually have some ideas here.

As a side comment: there's something that terrifies me about the locked
down nature of iPhones -- they prevent you from messing with the basic
experience with using the device. This seems contrary to the message of
apples famous 1984 ad, which champions the potential of computers as a way
to empower people instead of empowering corporate overlords to control
people.

html_content:
I would want it to be systemwide. This is something that I have previously called "augmented virtuality" and Kevin Kwok called "augmented reality for framebuffers"

There are a ton of awesome things you could do with this.

I wonder if my friend Geza, who works on a completely awesome program called habitlab https://habitlab.stanford.edu/ which sits between you and your addictive apps/websites does things like swap out Facebook with duolingo if you're on it too long, might actually have some ideas here.

As a side comment: there's something that terrifies me about the locked down nature of iPhones -- they prevent you from messing with the basic experience with using the device. This seems contrary to the message of apples famous 1984 ad, which champions the potential of computers as a way to empower people instead of empowering corporate overlords to control people.

subject: Re: Math/Stats question
content:
One way

Best,
Howon Lee

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 9:31 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:

> WOW.
>
> When you stretch it, do you always stretch it the same way or do you
> alternate between the two ways?
>
> On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 9:09 AM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
>
>> Smale horseshow is the attractor set of a dynamical map on the unit
>> square. The image in your head is that of a taffy machine
>> <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y7tlHDsquVM>. You stretch the unit
>> square by a factor >2 one axis of the square, and then compress in the
>> other axis by that same factor, getting a long rectangle. Then, you fold
>> the resulting rectangle back onto the square. Do that until you get to an
>> attractor in the phase space.
>>
>> The restriction is that the trajectories in the phase space of the thing
>> cannot cross. That seems like it would admit to a computational
>> simplification (lower computational complexity) for the inverse mapping.
>>
>> Best,
>> Howon Lee
>>
>> On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 8:59 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu>
>> wrote:
>>
>>> Great explanation of the Cantor Set, I got lost when we started talking
>>> about the horseshoe.
>>>
>>> On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:23 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
>>>
>>>> OK, so you know what the Cantor set is, it's the fractal defined on the
>>>> support [0,1] such that anything which is represented in the trinary
>>>> representation in the 2 is not a member of the set. Meaning, take out the
>>>> middle third of the support [0,1], take out the middle third of the 2/3
>>>> remaining, and so on.
>>>>
>>>> An alternate and nontrivial construction is to cut out the middle of
>>>> Smale's horseshoe.
>>>>
>>>> There's a lot of statistical work done on the inverse fractal problem,
>>>> much of it pretty amazingly useless. M Barnsley's group invented the
>>>> inverse IFS learning algorithm for this thing called fractal compression,
>>>> which after being featured on Microsoft Encarta 1998 never got use in real
>>>> places again.
>>>>
>>>> But that stuff depends upon the operation of affine transforms (it
>>>> searches parameter space in a non-terrible time because it assumes that the
>>>> fractal is generated from an affine iterative transform). Smale's horseshoe
>>>> is based on topologically different transforms, but it's still a limited
>>>> set of them, so they should be, if not feasible for search, at least
>>>> amenable to MCMC or something.
>>>>
>>>> Best,
>>>> Howon Lee
>>>>
>>>> On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:17 PM, Nikhil Buduma <nkbuduma@gmail.com>
>>>> wrote:
>>>>
>>>>> Yeah same can someone translate? Tried Wikipedia bashing with little
>>>>> avail
>>>>>
>>>>> On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 5:46 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu>
>>>>> wrote:
>>>>>
>>>>>> WOW this went way over my head.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> On Sun, Jun 7, 2015 at 4:20 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
>>>>>>
>>>>>>> So you can get a Cantor set by cutting the classical Smale horseshoe
>>>>>>> through the middle. Is there any body of statistical work which attempts
>>>>>>> the inverse problem: that is, looking at some fractal, getting the
>>>>>>> corresponding chaotic map? I'm aware of the symbolic dynamics literature
>>>>>>> and the IFS work, but I'm thinking topological stuff *like* the
>>>>>>> classic Smale horseshoe specifically.
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> Best,
>>>>>>> Howon Lee
>>>>>>>

html_content:
One way

Best,
Howon Lee

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 9:31 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
WOW.

When you stretch it, do you always stretch it the same way or do you alternate between the two ways?

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 9:09 AM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
Smale horseshow is the attractor set of a dynamical map on the unit square. The image in your head is that of a taffy machine. You stretch the unit square by a factor >2 one axis of the square, and then compress in the other axis by that same factor, getting a long rectangle. Then, you fold the resulting rectangle back onto the square. Do that until you get to an attractor in the phase space.

The restriction is that the trajectories in the phase space of the thing cannot cross. That seems like it would admit to a computational simplification (lower computational complexity) for the inverse mapping.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 8:59 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
Great explanation of the Cantor Set, I got lost when we started talking about the horseshoe.

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:23 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
OK, so you know what the Cantor set is, it's the fractal defined on the support [0,1] such that anything which is represented in the trinary representation in the 2 is not a member of the set. Meaning, take out the middle third of the support [0,1], take out the middle third of the 2/3 remaining, and so on.

An alternate and nontrivial construction is to cut out the middle of Smale's horseshoe.

There's a lot of statistical work done on the inverse fractal problem, much of it pretty amazingly useless. M Barnsley's group invented the inverse IFS learning algorithm for this thing called fractal compression, which after being featured on Microsoft Encarta 1998 never got use in real places again.

But that stuff depends upon the operation of affine transforms (it searches parameter space in a non-terrible time because it assumes that the fractal is generated from an affine iterative transform). Smale's horseshoe is based on topologically different transforms, but it's still a limited set of them, so they should be, if not feasible for search, at least amenable to MCMC or something.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:17 PM, Nikhil Buduma <nkbuduma@gmail.com> wrote:
Yeah same can someone translate? Tried Wikipedia bashing with little avail

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 5:46 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
WOW this went way over my head.

On Sun, Jun 7, 2015 at 4:20 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
So you can get a Cantor set by cutting the classical Smale horseshoe through the middle. Is there any body of statistical work which attempts the inverse problem: that is, looking at some fractal, getting the corresponding chaotic map? I'm aware of the symbolic dynamics literature and the IFS work, but I'm thinking topological stuff like the classic Smale horseshoe specifically.

Best,
Howon Lee

html_content:
WOW.

When you stretch it, do you always stretch it the same way or do you alternate between the two ways?

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 9:09 AM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
Smale horseshow is the attractor set of a dynamical map on the unit square. The image in your head is that of a taffy machine. You stretch the unit square by a factor >2 one axis of the square, and then compress in the other axis by that same factor, getting a long rectangle. Then, you fold the resulting rectangle back onto the square. Do that until you get to an attractor in the phase space.

The restriction is that the trajectories in the phase space of the thing cannot cross. That seems like it would admit to a computational simplification (lower computational complexity) for the inverse mapping.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 8:59 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
Great explanation of the Cantor Set, I got lost when we started talking about the horseshoe.

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:23 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
OK, so you know what the Cantor set is, it's the fractal defined on the support [0,1] such that anything which is represented in the trinary representation in the 2 is not a member of the set. Meaning, take out the middle third of the support [0,1], take out the middle third of the 2/3 remaining, and so on.

An alternate and nontrivial construction is to cut out the middle of Smale's horseshoe.

There's a lot of statistical work done on the inverse fractal problem, much of it pretty amazingly useless. M Barnsley's group invented the inverse IFS learning algorithm for this thing called fractal compression, which after being featured on Microsoft Encarta 1998 never got use in real places again.

But that stuff depends upon the operation of affine transforms (it searches parameter space in a non-terrible time because it assumes that the fractal is generated from an affine iterative transform). Smale's horseshoe is based on topologically different transforms, but it's still a limited set of them, so they should be, if not feasible for search, at least amenable to MCMC or something.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:17 PM, Nikhil Buduma <nkbuduma@gmail.com> wrote:
Yeah same can someone translate? Tried Wikipedia bashing with little avail

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 5:46 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
WOW this went way over my head.

On Sun, Jun 7, 2015 at 4:20 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
So you can get a Cantor set by cutting the classical Smale horseshoe through the middle. Is there any body of statistical work which attempts the inverse problem: that is, looking at some fractal, getting the corresponding chaotic map? I'm aware of the symbolic dynamics literature and the IFS work, but I'm thinking topological stuff like the classic Smale horseshoe specifically.

Best,
Howon Lee

html_content:
Smale horseshow is the attractor set of a dynamical map on the unit square. The image in your head is that of a taffy machine. You stretch the unit square by a factor >2 one axis of the square, and then compress in the other axis by that same factor, getting a long rectangle. Then, you fold the resulting rectangle back onto the square. Do that until you get to an attractor in the phase space.

The restriction is that the trajectories in the phase space of the thing cannot cross. That seems like it would admit to a computational simplification (lower computational complexity) for the inverse mapping.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 8:59 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
Great explanation of the Cantor Set, I got lost when we started talking about the horseshoe.

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:23 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
OK, so you know what the Cantor set is, it's the fractal defined on the support [0,1] such that anything which is represented in the trinary representation in the 2 is not a member of the set. Meaning, take out the middle third of the support [0,1], take out the middle third of the 2/3 remaining, and so on.

An alternate and nontrivial construction is to cut out the middle of Smale's horseshoe.

There's a lot of statistical work done on the inverse fractal problem, much of it pretty amazingly useless. M Barnsley's group invented the inverse IFS learning algorithm for this thing called fractal compression, which after being featured on Microsoft Encarta 1998 never got use in real places again.

But that stuff depends upon the operation of affine transforms (it searches parameter space in a non-terrible time because it assumes that the fractal is generated from an affine iterative transform). Smale's horseshoe is based on topologically different transforms, but it's still a limited set of them, so they should be, if not feasible for search, at least amenable to MCMC or something.

Best,
Howon Lee

I'm aware of the symbolic dynamics literature and the IFS work, but I'm thinking topological stuff like the classic Smale horseshoe specifically.

subject: Re: Math/Stats question
content:
OK, so you know what the Cantor set is, it's the fractal defined on the
support [0,1] such that anything which is represented in the trinary
representation in the 2 is not a member of the set. Meaning, take out the
middle third of the support [0,1], take out the middle third of the 2/3
remaining, and so on.

An alternate and nontrivial construction is to cut out the middle of
Smale's horseshoe.

There's a lot of statistical work done on the inverse fractal problem, much
of it pretty amazingly useless. M Barnsley's group invented the inverse IFS
learning algorithm for this thing called fractal compression, which after
being featured on Microsoft Encarta 1998 never got use in real places again.

But that stuff depends upon the operation of affine transforms (it searches
parameter space in a non-terrible time because it assumes that the fractal
is generated from an affine iterative transform). Smale's horseshoe is
based on topologically different transforms, but it's still a limited set
of them, so they should be, if not feasible for search, at least amenable
to MCMC or something.

Best,
Howon Lee

html_content:
OK, so you know what the Cantor set is, it's the fractal defined on the support [0,1] such that anything which is represented in the trinary representation in the 2 is not a member of the set. Meaning, take out the middle third of the support [0,1], take out the middle third of the 2/3 remaining, and so on.

An alternate and nontrivial construction is to cut out the middle of Smale's horseshoe.

There's a lot of statistical work done on the inverse fractal problem, much of it pretty amazingly useless. M Barnsley's group invented the inverse IFS learning algorithm for this thing called fractal compression, which after being featured on Microsoft Encarta 1998 never got use in real places again.

But that stuff depends upon the operation of affine transforms (it searches parameter space in a non-terrible time because it assumes that the fractal is generated from an affine iterative transform). Smale's horseshoe is based on topologically different transforms, but it's still a limited set of them, so they should be, if not feasible for search, at least amenable to MCMC or something.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:17 PM, Nikhil Buduma <nkbuduma@gmail.com> wrote:
Yeah same can someone translate? Tried Wikipedia bashing with little avail

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 5:46 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
WOW this went way over my head.

On Sun, Jun 7, 2015 at 4:20 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
So you can get a Cantor set by cutting the classical Smale horseshoe through the middle. Is there any body of statistical work which attempts the inverse problem: that is, looking at some fractal, getting the corresponding chaotic map? I'm aware of the symbolic dynamics literature and the IFS work, but I'm thinking topological stuff like the classic Smale horseshoe specifically.

Best,
Howon Lee

subject: Math/Stats question
content:
So you can get a Cantor set by cutting the classical Smale horseshoe
through the middle. Is there any body of statistical work which attempts
the inverse problem: that is, looking at some fractal, getting the
corresponding chaotic map? I'm aware of the symbolic dynamics literature
and the IFS work, but I'm thinking topological stuff *like* the classic
Smale horseshoe specifically.

Best,
Howon Lee
html_content:
So you can get a Cantor set by cutting the classical Smale horseshoe through the middle. Is there any body of statistical work which attempts the inverse problem: that is, looking at some fractal, getting the corresponding chaotic map? I'm aware of the symbolic dynamics literature and the IFS work, but I'm thinking topological stuff like the classic Smale horseshoe specifically.

Best,
Howon Lee

Greetings Hacksphere,

I work for a small managed WordPress hosting company. We are developing a platform, which is already largely developed.

Our team is interested in some UI/UX project assistance. We are currently going through some internal design processes.

I thought it would be interesting to reach out to Hacksphere and see what's out there. We are interested in hourly contract proposals with individuals or small teams.
