subject: UI/UX Project Interest
content:
Greetings Hacksphere,

I work for a small managed WordPress hosting company. We are developing a
platform, which is already largely developed.

Our team is interested in some UI/UX project assistance. We are currently
going through some internal design processes.

I thought it would be interesting to reach out to Hacksphere and see what's
out there. We are interested in hourly contract proposals with individuals
or small teams.

Please feel free to email me personally with recommendations or any
questions. We can have a meeting and go over any questions or details.

The requirements for the frontend of the platform are slim. We require a
suite of CRUD elements including permission management and some advanced
features in the future. We are looking at React and JQuery + Bootstrap
stacks.

Thank you very much,
JP Hayes
html_content:
Greetings Hacksphere,

I work for a small managed WordPress hosting company. We are developing a platform, which is already largely developed.

Our team is interested in some UI/UX project assistance. We are currently going through some internal design processes.

I thought it would be interesting to reach out to Hacksphere and see what's out there. We are interested in hourly contract proposals with individuals or small teams.

Please feel free to email me personally with recommendations or any questions. We can have a meeting and go over any questions or details.

The requirements for the frontend of the platform are slim. We require a suite of CRUD elements including permission management and some advanced features in the future. We are looking at React and JQuery + Bootstrap stacks.

Thank you very much,
JP Hayes

subject:
Re: Can you explain to a smart 10 year old why the volume of a cone
 is PI*r^2*h/3?
content:
In one dimension, it takes two little sticks to make a big stick.

In two dimensions, it takes four little triangles to make a square.

In three dimensions, it takes six pyramids to make a cube.

In four dimensions, it takes eight hyper-pyramids to make a hyper-cube.

html_content:
I set them to be 12 months when I'm signing up for them :P


On Wed, Nov 6, 2013 at 11:14 PM, chris gervang <chrisgervang@gmail.com> wrote:
Recently my .tk domains have been non-responsive. Jacob, do you renew all of these domains every 4 months? Or do they work without maintenance?

.Chris Gervang
From: Jacob Cole
Sent: ‎11/‎4/‎2013 8:18 PM
To: HackSphere@googlegroups.com

Subject: Re: My .tk domailns

I'd say they are as meaningful as any and really convenient.
Bit.ly's are uglier URLs that are less memorable.
Maybe I should make subdomains instead? But those are less memorable too.

One big thing I wish is that there were an auto-updated public list of the domains I shared. As an interim step I put a list of them on my minimalist homepage, http://jacobsstuffmin.tk/ (though I'm not sure they ultimately belong there).

More generally, I ultimately think it's just way too difficult for people to create content on the web right now, even with such innovations as Google Sites. I wish I could just quickly make a bunch of Google documents with reasonable URLs and link them to each other in a coherent way.



On Tue, Nov 5, 2013 at 3:31 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
Wow. I genuinely don't know. They are free and easy to get. Can you point to a specific alternative?

-- R


On Mon, Nov 4, 2013 at 7:31 PM, Juan Batiz-Benet <juan@benet.ai> wrote:
What is the point of .tk domains? Why not meaningful domains? Or URL shorteners? Or URL shorteners with meaningful keys?
—

html_content:
I'd say they are as meaningful as any and really convenient.
Bit.ly's are uglier URLs that are less memorable.
Maybe I should make subdomains instead? But those are less memorable too.

One big thing I wish is that there were an auto-updated public list of the domains I shared. As an interim step I put a list of them on my minimalist homepage, http://jacobsstuffmin.tk/ (though I'm not sure they ultimately belong there).

More generally, I ultimately think it's just way too difficult for people to create content on the web right now, even with such innovations as Google Sites. I wish I could just quickly make a bunch of Google documents with reasonable URLs and link them to each other in a coherent way.



On Tue, Nov 5, 2013 at 3:31 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
Wow. I genuinely don't know. They are free and easy to get. Can you point to a specific alternative?

-- R

subject: Re: Autocomplete
content:
@Lucas, good point.

I have been meaning to learn Chef and experiment with Vagrant, but they're
on a very long to do list!

On Sun, Dec 16, 2012 at 9:16 PM, Lucas Hansen <lucashansen@gmail.com> wrote:

> Oh man Vagrant is the most convenient thing since sliced bread... I used
> it in combination with Chef http://www.opscode.com/chef/, and I could
> provision a new VM fully loaded with a dev environment in about 2 minutes.
>
> And if your normal dev environment is a headless Linux server then there
> is really very little difference between SSH'ing into a box and having the
> environment setup directly on your machine.
>
>
> On Sun, Dec 16, 2012 at 10:11 PM, John YS <johnyangsam@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>> @Lucas, not until you showed me. This is pretty awesome! Exactly what I
>> was talking about!...Brings up another question of how I didn't know about
>> the site until you mentioned it -> I feel like distribution for software
>> resources is still mainly oral knowledge and word of mouth.
>>
>> @Jacob, I have been thinking about an easy to deploy platform since the
>> pain of getting my dev environment setup at my last internship, but it
>> comes down to a hardware problem, right? At the end of the day someone has
>> to write spaghetti code to make a common platform (OS or otherwise) that
>> everything else can build off of.
>>
>> Have you seen Vagrant? http://vagrantup.com/.
>>
>> It comes close, but I still want to have my dev env as close to the
>> computer as possible and not have the extra layer of indirection with a VM
>> (though that might be a silly thing for me to say)
>>
>>
>> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 2:58 PM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:
>>
>>> There was a stanford startup that helped you search for code snippets
>>> inline I saw at admit weekend years ago called Blueprint which got acquired
>>> by adobe, and discontinued <
>>> http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/blueprint/> for some reason...
>>>
>>> What I'm really interested in doing is creating a project I might call
>>> UILabs, or UIRemix, which would let you really quickly build apps of any
>>> sort in the UX-first direction. You might even be able to even mix in UX
>>> elements of existing sites/apps. You could share your UX improvements to
>>> existing apps online, so everybody could have their computer user
>>> experiences customized like Jacob, for instance, has his customized. This
>>> relates to the phenomenon that one-click setup/install is something very
>>> necessary and obvious, as I expound in the email I just sent titled "a
>>> modest proposal." (cmon it can take HOURS to learn to setup a service like
>>> Heroku for the first time. If Blizzard were selling web dev through Heroku
>>> as a game, nobody would buy it/play it if it were that hard to install.)
>>> More generally, I feel like many of these UI features are very obvious,
>>> and I'm curious why they don't exist already. I'm often more impressed by
>>> enterprise software like Microsoft Visual Studio on this front.
>>>
>>>
>>> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 3:23 PM, Lucas Hansen <lucashansen@gmail.com>wrote:
>>>
>>>> @John
>>>> Have you seen http://rosettacode.org/ ?
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 12:25 PM, Turner Bohlen <turnerbohlen@gmail.com
>>>> > wrote:
>>>>
>>>>> That would be fantastic.....
>>>>>
>>>>> I'm sure we could convince github to donate some large part of their
>>>>> website code base to begin development. I think they would love to help.
>>>>> Wrap that up with a wiki, and you're good to go.
>>>>>
>>>>> Turner Bohlen
>>>>> www.turnerbohlen.com
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 1:18 PM, John YS <johnyangsam@gmail.com>wrote:
>>>>>
>>>>>> How about a "wikipedia of code." One that has every algorithm in
>>>>>> every language, public availably to edit in a kind of fork/pull request
>>>>>> format?
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 9:16 AM, Carl Gao <cgao117@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>>>>
>>>>>>> This sounds pretty interesting - I've thought that having a side
>>>>>>> pane in my IDE that is exclusively a search engine for code snippets would
>>>>>>> be crazy useful. Most of the time when I search on Google or Stack
>>>>>>> Overflow, I'm really just looking for example code similar to what I need
>>>>>>> to accomplish anyway. Yeah - perhaps just having it as a reference instead
>>>>>>> of an autocomplete feature would be more optimal, as Neal said.
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> In terms of variants on common problems - you could display all
>>>>>>> those options and allow the user to specify what they want to optimize for?
>>>>>>> For example, upon typing "BFS(Graph G)", the IDE would ask "if you know,
>>>>>>> around what size will your Graph be?" etc. Of course, the data backing this
>>>>>>> up would have to be quite robust and well-organized, but it would be
>>>>>>> awesome if this could happen :]
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> Also, I really like how this fits into the "social coding" paradigm!
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> On Fri, Dec 7, 2012 at 3:08 PM, Neal Wu <neal@nealwu.com> wrote:
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>> Yeah, interesting idea. I don't think it would make sense for
>>>>>>>> functions as high-level as BFS though, because there are lots of variants
>>>>>>>> that you may or may not want to follow, and there are lots of different
>>>>>>>> results you could be trying to obtain. It would work for small functions
>>>>>>>> like square(x), but those are easy enough that they don't cause much pain.
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>> What I would like though would be to be able to just read code from
>>>>>>>> other people that's similar to yours. If you get stuck writing something it
>>>>>>>> could at least provide you with some inspiration. :)
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>> On Fri, Dec 7, 2012 at 12:01 PM, Rafael Cosman <
>>>>>>>> rafaelcosman@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>> Here's an idea I've been entertaining recently. Jacob Cole, I
>>>>>>>>> think this one is right up your alley.
>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>> I've seen way too many programmers write duplicate code. Code that
>>>>>>>>> you know has already been written dozens of times before. Code that could
>>>>>>>>> easily be found in a library or in an open-source project online.
>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>> Imagine using an IDE that didn't just auto-complete variable names
>>>>>>>>> for you, but auto-completed entire method definitions or even entire
>>>>>>>>> classes. You type "BFS(Graph G)" and the IDE immediately offers you the
>>>>>>>>> entire method definition by running a search on Git-hub.
>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>> In exchange, the IDE would politely ask you to make publicly
>>>>>>>>> available any non-top-secret code that you write. It'd give a whole new
>>>>>>>>> meaning to 'social coding'.
>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>> -- Rafael
>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> --
>>> Jacob
>>> qoɔɐɾ
>>>
>>> jcole@mit.edu
>>> dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
>>> tmad4000@gmail.com
>>> (858) 740-6970
>>>
>>>
>>
>
html_content:
@Lucas, good point.

I have been meaning to learn Chef and experiment with Vagrant, but they're on a very long to do list!

On Sun, Dec 16, 2012 at 9:16 PM, Lucas Hansen <lucashansen@gmail.com> wrote:
Oh man Vagrant is the most convenient thing since sliced bread... I used it in combination with Chef http://www.opscode.com/chef/, and I could provision a new VM fully loaded with a dev environment in about 2 minutes. 

And if your normal dev environment is a headless Linux server then there is really very little difference between SSH'ing into a box and having the environment setup directly on your machine.


On Sun, Dec 16, 2012 at 10:11 PM, John YS <johnyangsam@gmail.com> wrote:
@Lucas, not until you showed me. This is pretty awesome! Exactly what I was talking about!...Brings up another question of how I didn't know about the site until you mentioned it -> I feel like distribution for software resources is still mainly oral knowledge and word of mouth.

@Jacob, I have been thinking about an easy to deploy platform since the pain of getting my dev environment setup at my last internship, but it comes down to a hardware problem, right? At the end of the day someone has to write spaghetti code to make a common platform (OS or otherwise) that everything else can build off of.

Have you seen Vagrant? http://vagrantup.com/.

It comes close, but I still want to have my dev env as close to the computer as possible and not have the extra layer of indirection with a VM (though that might be a silly thing for me to say)


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 2:58 PM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:
There was a stanford startup that helped you search for code snippets inline I saw at admit weekend years ago called Blueprint which got acquired by adobe, and discontinued <http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/blueprint/> for some reason...

What I'm really interested in doing is creating a project I might call UILabs, or UIRemix, which would let you really quickly build apps of any sort in the UX-first direction. You might even be able to even mix in UX elements of existing sites/apps. You could share your UX improvements to existing apps online, so everybody could have their computer user experiences customized like Jacob, for instance, has his customized. This relates to the phenomenon that one-click setup/install is something very necessary and obvious, as I expound in the email I just sent titled "a modest proposal." (cmon it can take HOURS to learn to setup a service like Heroku for the first time. If Blizzard were selling web dev through Heroku as a game, nobody would buy it/play it if it were that hard to install.)
More generally, I feel like many of these UI features are very obvious, and I'm curious why they don't exist already. I'm often more impressed by enterprise software like Microsoft Visual Studio on this front.


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 3:23 PM, Lucas Hansen <lucashansen@gmail.com> wrote:
@John
Have you seen http://rosettacode.org/ ?


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 12:25 PM, Turner Bohlen <turnerbohlen@gmail.com> wrote:
That would be fantastic.....

I'm sure we could convince github to donate some large part of their website code base to begin development. I think they would love to help. Wrap that up with a wiki, and you're good to go.

Turner Bohlen
www.turnerbohlen.com



On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 1:18 PM, John YS <johnyangsam@gmail.com> wrote:
How about a "wikipedia of code." One that has every algorithm in every language, public availably to edit in a kind of fork/pull request format?


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 9:16 AM, Carl Gao <cgao117@gmail.com> wrote:
This sounds pretty interesting - I've thought that having a side pane in my IDE that is exclusively a search engine for code snippets would be crazy useful. Most of the time when I search on Google or Stack Overflow, I'm really just looking for example code similar to what I need to accomplish anyway. Yeah - perhaps just having it as a reference instead of an autocomplete feature would be more optimal, as Neal said. 

In terms of variants on common problems - you could display all those options and allow the user to specify what they want to optimize for? For example, upon typing "BFS(Graph G)", the IDE would ask "if you know, around what size will your Graph be?" etc. Of course, the data backing this up would have to be quite robust and well-organized, but it would be awesome if this could happen :]

Also, I really like how this fits into the "social coding" paradigm! 


On Fri, Dec 7, 2012 at 3:08 PM, Neal Wu <neal@nealwu.com> wrote:
Yeah, interesting idea. I don't think it would make sense for functions as high-level as BFS though, because there are lots of variants that you may or may not want to follow, and there are lots of different results you could be trying to obtain. It would work for small functions like square(x), but those are easy enough that they don't cause much pain.

What I would like though would be to be able to just read code from other people that's similar to yours. If you get stuck writing something it could at least provide you with some inspiration. :)


On Fri, Dec 7, 2012 at 12:01 PM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@gmail.com> wrote:
Here's an idea I've been entertaining recently. Jacob Cole, I think this one is right up your alley.

I've seen way too many programmers write duplicate code. Code that you know has already been written dozens of times before. Code that could easily be found in a library or in an open-source project online.

Imagine using an IDE that didn't just auto-complete variable names for you, but auto-completed entire method definitions or even entire classes. You type "BFS(Graph G)" and the IDE immediately offers you the entire method definition by running a search on Git-hub.

In exchange, the IDE would politely ask you to make publicly available any non-top-secret code that you write. It'd give a whole new meaning to 'social coding'.

-- Rafael








--
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970

subject:
Re: If I wanted to make a simple client app to make lists, what would
 I write it in?
content:
You can have a desktop app that is just a webview and then code it however
you'd do it in the browser.
The "backend" would be some local process serving from an obscure port port.
This is how light table is built and I think it's the easiest way for webby
people to build a frontend-heavy desktop app. This would even let you share
code with the in-browser version!

You can have a desktop app that is just a webview and then code it however you'd do it in the browser.
The "backend" would be some local process serving from an obscure port port.
This is how light table is built and I think it's the easiest way for webby people to build a frontend-heavy desktop app. This would even let you share code with the in-browser version!

subject: Re: Autocomplete
content:
@Lucas, not until you showed me. This is pretty awesome! Exactly what I was
talking about!...Brings up another question of how I didn't know about the
site until you mentioned it -> I feel like distribution for software
resources is still mainly oral knowledge and word of mouth.

@Jacob, I have been thinking about an easy to deploy platform since the
pain of getting my dev environment setup at my last internship, but it
comes down to a hardware problem, right? At the end of the day someone has
to write spaghetti code to make a common platform (OS or otherwise) that
everything else can build off of.

Have you seen Vagrant? http://vagrantup.com/.

It comes close, but I still want to have my dev env as close to the
computer as possible and not have the extra layer of indirection with a VM
(though that might be a silly thing for me to say)

@Jacob, I have been thinking about an easy to deploy platform since the pain of getting my dev environment setup at my last internship, but it comes down to a hardware problem, right? At the end of the day someone has to write spaghetti code to make a common platform (OS or otherwise) that everything else can build off of.

Have you seen Vagrant? http://vagrantup.com/.

It comes close, but I still want to have my dev env as close to the computer as possible and not have the extra layer of indirection with a VM (though that might be a silly thing for me to say)

On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 2:58 PM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:
There was a stanford startup that helped you search for code snippets inline I saw at admit weekend years ago called Blueprint which got acquired by adobe, and discontinued <http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/blueprint/> for some reason...

What I'm really interested in doing is creating a project I might call UILabs, or UIRemix, which would let you really quickly build apps of any sort in the UX-first direction. You might even be able to even mix in UX elements of existing sites/apps. You could share your UX improvements to existing apps online, so everybody could have their computer user experiences customized like Jacob, for instance, has his customized. This relates to the phenomenon that one-click setup/install is something very necessary and obvious, as I expound in the email I just sent titled "a modest proposal." (cmon it can take HOURS to learn to setup a service like Heroku for the first time. If Blizzard were selling web dev through Heroku as a game, nobody would buy it/play it if it were that hard to install.)
More generally, I feel like many of these UI features are very obvious, and I'm curious why they don't exist already. I'm often more impressed by enterprise software like Microsoft Visual Studio on this front.


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 3:23 PM, Lucas Hansen <lucashansen@gmail.com> wrote:
@John
Have you seen http://rosettacode.org/ ?


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 12:25 PM, Turner Bohlen <turnerbohlen@gmail.com> wrote:
That would be fantastic.....

I'm sure we could convince github to donate some large part of their website code base to begin development. I think they would love to help. Wrap that up with a wiki, and you're good to go.

Turner Bohlen
www.turnerbohlen.com



On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 1:18 PM, John YS <johnyangsam@gmail.com> wrote:
How about a "wikipedia of code." One that has every algorithm in every language, public availably to edit in a kind of fork/pull request format?


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 9:16 AM, Carl Gao <cgao117@gmail.com> wrote:
This sounds pretty interesting - I've thought that having a side pane in my IDE that is exclusively a search engine for code snippets would be crazy useful. Most of the time when I search on Google or Stack Overflow, I'm really just looking for example code similar to what I need to accomplish anyway. Yeah - perhaps just having it as a reference instead of an autocomplete feature would be more optimal, as Neal said. 

In terms of variants on common problems - you could display all those options and allow the user to specify what they want to optimize for? For example, upon typing "BFS(Graph G)", the IDE would ask "if you know, around what size will your Graph be?" etc. Of course, the data backing this up would have to be quite robust and well-organized, but it would be awesome if this could happen :]

Also, I really like how this fits into the "social coding" paradigm! 


On Fri, Dec 7, 2012 at 3:08 PM, Neal Wu <neal@nealwu.com> wrote:
Yeah, interesting idea. I don't think it would make sense for functions as high-level as BFS though, because there are lots of variants that you may or may not want to follow, and there are lots of different results you could be trying to obtain. It would work for small functions like square(x), but those are easy enough that they don't cause much pain.

What I would like though would be to be able to just read code from other people that's similar to yours. If you get stuck writing something it could at least provide you with some inspiration. :)


On Fri, Dec 7, 2012 at 12:01 PM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@gmail.com> wrote:
Here's an idea I've been entertaining recently. Jacob Cole, I think this one is right up your alley.

I've seen way too many programmers write duplicate code. Code that you know has already been written dozens of times before. Code that could easily be found in a library or in an open-source project online.

Imagine using an IDE that didn't just auto-complete variable names for you, but auto-completed entire method definitions or even entire classes. You type "BFS(Graph G)" and the IDE immediately offers you the entire method definition by running a search on Git-hub.

In exchange, the IDE would politely ask you to make publicly available any non-top-secret code that you write. It'd give a whole new meaning to 'social coding'.

-- Rafael








--
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970

subject: Re: What was the last thing you built/coded and who did you do it with?
content:
Wake, an alarm app that wakes you up gently using a gradual sound and
vibration ramp-up, and can be set to only stop ringing if you do 20 jumping
jacks. Accelerometer-based jumping jack detection is looking promising
(still in progress). With Richie Zeng, my high school BFF and now Hacker @
Berkeley whose team won PennApps this year.

subject: IDEO is hiring creative coders, makers, and hackers!
content:
Hey Hacksphere!

I'm a software designer at IDEO, a design and innovation consulting firm
based in Palo Alto and we're hiring!

*What does IDEO do?*
At it's core, IDEO is about gathering an antidisciplinary group of talented
people and letting them play and explore to find solutions to ambiguous and
systematic problems. That means applying the creative process to the
gnarliest industries such as healthcare and government to the newest such
as AR/VR, augmented intelligence, and autonomous vehicles. Recent public
work include:

   - A new voting machine
   <https://www.ideo.com/case-study/a-new-way-to-vote-for-the-people-of-los-angeles>
   for Los Angeles, focusing on accessibility and adaptability
   - The first portable, wearable breast pump
   <https://www.ideo.com/case-study/designing-the-first-all-in-one-wearable-breast-pump>
   - A interactive musical installation using giant beach balls
   <https://labs.ideo.com/2016/07/18/how-we-did-it-ideos-beach-ball-synth-for-moogfest/>
   - A business and app around socially-conscious investing
   <https://www.ideo.com/case-study/designing-a-fintech-startup-for-socially-conscious-investors>
   - and more! <https://www.ideo.com/work>

*What's the work like?*
Ambiguous, collaborative, frontier. Say your working to improve the
hospital waiting room experience. Your team might consist of an
anthropologist, an 3D-visual artist, an industrial designer, and a
neurosurgeon. You might spend a few days in a hospital interviewing patient
and doing field research. Then you might spend another few days making a
fully-functional React/iOS prototype or maybe an ESP8266-IoT enabled
device. You might make your own pop-up clinic in a parking lot, don a
doctor's smock, and run volunteers through a mock experience. Regardless of
the media or the technology, you'll run live field tests, iterating and
incubating new ideas before presenting it all to the board of a F500
company, a startup, or non-profit. Fast forward a few months, and you might
see your ideas and prototypes on the market!

*How do I apply?*
Check out the job posting and apply here.
<https://www.ideo.com/jobs/software/palo-alto/974920/software-designer> Feel
free to reach out to me at yc@ideo.com.

Cheers,
YC
html_content:
Hey Hacksphere!

I'm a software designer at IDEO, a design and innovation consulting firm based in Palo Alto and we're hiring!

What does IDEO do?
At it's core, IDEO is about gathering an antidisciplinary group of talented people and letting them play and explore to find solutions to ambiguous and systematic problems. That means applying the creative process to the gnarliest industries such as healthcare and government to the newest such as AR/VR, augmented intelligence, and autonomous vehicles. Recent public work include:
  • A new voting machine for Los Angeles, focusing on accessibility and adaptability 
  • The first portable, wearable breast pump
  • A interactive musical installation using giant beach balls
  • A business and app around socially-conscious investing
  • and more!
What's the work like?
Ambiguous, collaborative, frontier. Say your working to improve the hospital waiting room experience. Your team might consist of an anthropologist, an 3D-visual artist, an industrial designer, and a neurosurgeon. You might spend a few days in a hospital interviewing patient and doing field research. Then you might spend another few days making a fully-functional React/iOS prototype or maybe an ESP8266-IoT enabled device. You might make your own pop-up clinic in a parking lot, don a doctor's smock, and run volunteers through a mock experience. Regardless of the media or the technology, you'll run live field tests, iterating and incubating new ideas before presenting it all to the board of a F500 company, a startup, or non-profit. Fast forward a few months, and you might see your ideas and prototypes on the market!

How do I apply?
Check out the job posting and apply here. Feel free to reach out to me at yc@ideo.com.

Cheers,
YC

subject: Re: Software to help with Software transitions
content:
You could probably prototype with Apple Script and Automator! Boom!
-- 
Chris Gervang
Sent with Airmail

From: Rafael Cosman rafaelc@stanford.edu
Reply: hacksphere@googlegroups.com hacksphere@googlegroups.com
Date: March 17, 2014 at 9:12:51 AM
To: hacksphere@googlegroups.com hacksphere@googlegroups.com, H. Lee howonlee@stanford.edu
Subject:  Re: Software to help with Software transitions  

Boom! Specifying arbitrary intentions to your computer. This could be like If This Than That but it would work locally on your own machine.


Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael's Schedule

From: H. Lee howonlee@stanford.edu
Reply: hacksphere@googlegroups.com hacksphere@googlegroups.com
Date: March 17, 2014 at 8:40:23 AM
To: hacksphere@googlegroups.com hacksphere@googlegroups.com
Subject:  Re: Software to help with Software transitions

Let's try the Lally paper.

Best Regards,
Howon Lee


On Mon, Mar 17, 2014 at 8:34 AM, H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
This is a concrete instance of the abstract problem of habit change.

The literature has the most general method of habit change, due to Gollwitzer. It's called an implementation intention, and it's pretty ridiculous:

Say,

"If ___ (condition),

I will ____ (action)"

A concrete example comes from one of Gollwitzer's experiment with heroin addicts. If you ask a heroin addict to compose a CV for you, they have a success rate at doing this of about 0 percent. If you ask them to say, "If ___ (a condition that involves a specific time and place), I will write the CV", lots of them did. Gollwitzer apparently habitually promotes this thing, but here it is: http://www.psych.nyu.edu/gollwitzer/01BrandLengGoll_ActInit.pdf

If you think it's ridiculous, you should just try it. The caveat is those sample sizes!

I've studied this at some length, actually, so you can ask questions. Probably another interesting point is the regressions that Phillipa Lally did for how long it takes to form a habit: 15 to 250 days (250 days is an extrapolation, the study lasted 84 days). Most her papers are pretty cool (http://www.ucl.ac.uk/hbrc/diet/lallyp.html). This is How are habits formed: Modelling habit formation in the real world. That paper, I don't have any annoying methodological problems with, but I did a "ooh, cool charts!" reading of that one. I'm not sure about how to get it without journal access, so if you're interested in reading it for yourself, you should reply back or something. (I dunno: are attachments possible for Google Groups?)

There's an interesting piece of misinformation floating around about how it takes 21 days. Actual experience should tell you that's a load of crock, but the source of the factoid is interesting. A plastic surgeon named Maxwell Maltz noticed that his patients recovered from the self-image difference from plastic surgery about 21 days after the surgery, and talked to other surgeons about it, getting a bunch of anecdotal evidence that people generally do that for non-plastic surgeries as well. He also did the reading on Norbert Weiner's cybernetics, and therefore concluded that the self-image was a self-regulatory process a la cybernetics. Reasonable, but the timeframe for the habit was fairly off.

The other interesting part about Maltz is that he started promulgating this idea that visualization has this modality of action where it will do everything for you. Actually, he gives a lot of examples of visualization being excellent fake practice, for which there's a lot of good evidence. So The Secret and other scummy books like it are intellectual heritors of this book.

Probably the best individual book for actually reading about habit change is Baumeister's Willpower, it's a good lay reading. The less lay reading is The Handbook of Self-Regulation, edited by Baumeister and co. You can find that on the internet fairly easily.

(this is what I do instead of studying for finals...)

Best Regards,
Howon Lee


On Mon, Mar 17, 2014 at 5:37 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
We all make transitions in the software that we use. It might be useful to have a tool for making these transitions smoother.

I’ve recently moved from Sublime to Atom, but I still often open Sublime by accident. Just out of habit, or because an extensions is still associated with Sublime. I don’t want to remove Sublime from my system (because I expect I may still need it in the future, and it’s still a great piece of software that I’m proud to have) but I want help remembering to use Atom instead of Sublime. Because I’ve made a conscious decision to make this switch, my computer should help me.

Imagine a simple application where I select “Transition from [Sublime] -> [Atom]” (those are drop down menus) and then it will help me to use Atom whenever I would have otherwise used Sublime. Like whenever Sublime would open, instead this application makes a popup saying 

“Are you sure you want to open this file in Sublime? Atom may be a better choice”
buttons: [Use Sublime]   [Use Atom]

Rev2 of this software will train you to use the new hotkeys whenever you try to use the old ones. Thankfully with Atom/Sublime the hotkeys are almost identical.



— Rafa

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael's Schedule

subject:
Fwd: [OGM] Neural networks vs. Neocortical processes (was: Noam
 Chomsky: The False Promise of ChatGPT)
content:
Interesting thread— would love to discuss!

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Jacob Cole <jacob@ideaflow.io>
Date: Tue, Mar 21, 2023 at 12:16 AM
Subject: Fwd: [OGM] Neural networks vs. Neocortical processes (was: Noam
Chomsky: The False Promise of ChatGPT)
To: Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com>




---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Peter Kaminski <kaminski@istori.com>
Date: Fri, Mar 17, 2023 at 7:45 AM
Subject: [OGM] Neural networks vs. Neocortical processes (was: Noam
Chomsky: The False Promise of ChatGPT)
To: Ken Homer <kenhomer@sonic.net>, Jerry Michalski <sociate@gmail.com>,
Open Global Mind <openglobalmind@googlegroups.com>


> [Hawkins] does make the point that most neural nets are not based on the
way the human brain processes information and ultimately will fail as AIs
unless they make some major changes.
>
> Maybe Pete can give a better accounting of that part of his book, Pete,
are you up for that challenge?

Sure thing, Ken. And thank you for turning me onto, and helping me get
into, his "Thousand Brains" book.

For me, it's been sort of an extension of the story I originally learned
via neurophysiologist William Calvin and his "How Brains Think" books:

- How Brains Think, http://williamcalvin.com/bk8/
- Cerebral Code, http://williamcalvin.com/bk9/

Calvin was where I first heard of cortical columns. Where Hawkins describes
"voting" between cortical columns, Calvin describes something similar, but
likens the proceeding of the vote sort of like a choir recruiting new
voices, or as a Darwinian process between concepts, played out over the
population of cortical columns.

Hawkins' explanation of how brains think has more components than just
voting, because he's 25-30 years farther along in research than Calvin's
work from the mid-90's.

Anyway, artificial neural networks were inspired by the way biological
neurons work, but they're simplified models of real neurons.

And even though current AIs use many, many neurons, they're still not
arranged to form cortical columns, etc., and they're not used in the same
way a real brain with a neocortex uses neurons.

Please take the following with a grain of salt; I'm not a
neurophysiologist, and this is just my poor understanding from reading
Hawkins and Calvin.  I may have important parts over-simplified, or even
wrong.

Cortical columns are semi-autonomous "sensory-motor" brain structures
formed of several tens of thousands of neurons. Each cortical column
develops "models" of the outside world from the sensory inputs it receives
(some get input from vision, some from touch, some from hearing, etc.), and
can model hundreds of different things.

The models include a "reference frame".  You can think of a reference frame
as something like the grid system in a paper map, although reference frames
are not limited to two dimensions; they might have just one dimension, or
more than two, more than three, etc.

As a human moves through physical or conceptual space, sensory inputs to
the ~150,000 cortical columns change, and all the cortical columns do
parallel "predictions" of what sensory inputs will come next, based on
their reading of their models and reference maps.  When sensory input and
the predictions don't match, that is "learning".

Hawkins' observes that current AIs are typically pre-trained, and have a
simplified single task, of say, recognizing what image inputs correspond to
what object, due to similarities and differences learned in training and
then observed in a particular image.

In the "thousand brains" model, though, there are many -- possibly
thousands -- of interlocking models, that assess sensory input not just in
one mode (say, vision), but in multiple modes simultaneously.  The cortical
columns cooperate in a "vote" to develop, in your brain, a consensus
understanding of what they're perceiving.

The key hallmarks of real intelligence for Hawkins (p. 149 et seq.) are:

1. Learning continuously. Not pre-trained; literally learning with every
movement. Hawkins writes, "The most important component of how brains learn
continuously is the neuron. When a neuron learns a new pattern, it forms
new synapses on one dendrite branch. The new synapses don't affect
previously learned ones on other branches. Thus, learning something new
doesn't force the neuron to forget or modify something it learned earlier.
The artificial neurons used in today's AI systems don't have this ability.
This is one reason they can't learn continuously."

2. Learning via movement. "We cannot sense everything in the world at once;
therefore, movement is required for learning."  (By "movement" here,
Hawkins means both actual physical movement, and conceptual movement, such
as moving through a sequence of notes in a song, or reading a list of
democratic principles.)

3. Many models, as described above. "Knowledge about any particular thing,
such as a coffee cup,
is distributed among many complementary models." (What it looks like, what
it feels like when you touch it in different ways, how the the way it looks
different when you pick it up and move it around to different angles, what
you've observed happen when you turn it upside down when there's liquid in
it, etc., etc.)

4. Using reference frames to store knowledge. "Most artificial neural
networks have nothing equivalent to reference frames. For example, a
typical neural network that recognizes images just assigns a label to each
image. Without reference frames, the network has no way of learning the 3D
structure of objects or how they move and change. One of the problems with
a system like this is that we can't ask why it labeled something a cat. The
AI system doesn't know what a cat is. There is no further information to be
had, beyond that this image is similar to other images that were labeled
'cat.'"

Hawkins writes about his list of attributes: "My proposal for what
qualifies as intelligent is based on the brain. Each of the four attributes
in the following list is something we know that the brain does and that I
believe an
intelligent machine [AGI] must do too. Not everyone will agree with my
choice of attributes. One can make a good argument that I have left some
important things out. That's OK. I view my list as a minimum, or baseline,
for AGI. Few AI systems have any of these attributes today."

I recommend reading the whole book, not just this short summary. Hawkins'
book does a good job of making the topic much more clear. But hopefully
this gives you a taste of the difference Hawkins draws between current AI
and real intelligence.

Pete


--

When a neuron learns a new pattern, it forms new synapses on one dendrite branch. The new synapses don't affect previously learned ones on other branches. Thus, learning something new doesn't force the neuron to forget or modify something it learned earlier. The artificial neurons used in today's AI systems don't have this ability. This is one reason they can't learn continuously."

2. Learning via movement. "We cannot sense everything in the world at once; therefore, movement is required for learning."  (By "movement" here, Hawkins means both actual physical movement, and conceptual movement, such as moving through a sequence of notes in a song, or reading a list of democratic principles.)

3. Many models, as described above. "Knowledge about any particular thing, such as a coffee cup,
is distributed among many complementary models." (What it looks like, what it feels like when you touch it in different ways, how the the way it looks different when you pick it up and move it around to different angles, what you've observed happen when you turn it upside down when there's liquid in it, etc., etc.)

4. Using reference frames to store knowledge. "Most artificial neural networks have nothing equivalent to reference frames. For example, a typical neural network that recognizes images just assigns a label to each image. One of the problems with a system like this is that we can't ask why it labeled something a cat. The AI system doesn't know what a cat is. There is no further information to be had, beyond that this image is similar to other images that were labeled 'cat.'"

Hawkins writes about his list of attributes: "My proposal for what qualifies as intelligent is based on the brain. Each of the four attributes in the following list is something we know that the brain does and that I believe an
intelligent machine [AGI] must do too. Not everyone will agree with my choice of attributes. One can make a good argument that I have left some important things out. That's OK. I view my list as a minimum, or baseline, for AGI. Few AI systems have any of these attributes today."

subject: Re: Ideas for Advertising Kickstarter Project
content:
hey long time no see Victor!

Makerfaires would be a cool idea, but I don't think any are happening till
your close date. Bay Area MF just finished up.

Not sure how to go about it, but getting featured on Engadget/Gizmodo/etc
would create a lot of traffic or even getting posted to some big facebook
pages.
Could always start with getting featured on some small tech blogs and maybe
the big ones will pick you up. Or maybe just send one to engadget and see
what happens lol.

Product looks cool, I assume you need the large backing for the mold
injecting. Personally I would love to see how durable the final
design/material choice is, how I usually pick my iphone cases (otterbox
atm). Also for a future revision maybe integrate some kind of wireless
charging circuit such as the Qi featured on many android phones would be a
sweet combo if the price is right.

Best of luck!
Mark

On Tue, May 19, 2015 at 7:55 AM, Rebecca Li <rmli@mit.edu> wrote:

> Makerfaires often work as okay advertising, people sell their random
> gadgets and printers there.
>
> Try to get articles written about your gadget? Do a giveaway promo with
> Engadget or someone else, to get on people's "tech radar".
>
> You could also try selling it as a magic phone case that both protects and
> powers. On your kickstarter, the blurb about protecting your phone and
> ejecting  is not as compelling as it should be, and it feels out of place.
> A bit like an addition, not a well thought feature. You're selling to Apple
> consumers, so you should take on the apple branding that this is a magic
> lifestyle choice case that rescues you from the tyranny of lightening ports
> and cracked screens with a fashionable sleek blue case that acts as the
> Guardian angel of your phone. With chamfers.
> Okay maybe not that far but consumers are expecting a polished apple
> product for their apple product, and displaying that through cohesive
> design is important.
>
> Hope that was helpful,
>
> Rebecca
>
> --
> You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups
> "HackSphere" group.
> To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an
> email to HackSphere+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.
> For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.
>



-- 
-Mark Liu
html_content:
hey long time no see Victor! 

Makerfaires would be a cool idea, but I don't think any are happening till your close date. Bay Area MF just finished up. 

Not sure how to go about it, but getting featured on Engadget/Gizmodo/etc would create a lot of traffic or even getting posted to some big facebook pages.
Could always start with getting featured on some small tech blogs and maybe the big ones will pick you up. Or maybe just send one to engadget and see what happens lol. 

Product looks cool, I assume you need the large backing for the mold injecting. Personally I would love to see how durable the final design/material choice is, how I usually pick my iphone cases (otterbox atm). Also for a future revision maybe integrate some kind of wireless charging circuit such as the Qi featured on many android phones would be a sweet combo if the price is right. 

Best of luck! 
Mark

On Tue, May 19, 2015 at 7:55 AM, Rebecca Li <rmli@mit.edu> wrote:

Makerfaires often work as okay advertising, people sell their random gadgets and printers there.

Try to get articles written about your gadget? Do a giveaway promo with Engadget or someone else, to get on people's "tech radar".

You could also try selling it as a magic phone case that both protects and powers. On your kickstarter, the blurb about protecting your phone and ejecting  is not as compelling as it should be, and it feels out of place. A bit like an addition, not a well thought feature. You're selling to Apple consumers, so you should take on the apple branding that this is a magic lifestyle choice case that rescues you from the tyranny of lightening ports and cracked screens with a fashionable sleek blue case that acts as the Guardian angel of your phone. With chamfers.
Okay maybe not that far but consumers are expecting a polished apple product for their apple product, and displaying that through cohesive design is important.

Hope that was helpful,

Rebecca

On Nov 24, 2020, at 2:28 PM, John Paul Hayes II <john.has.come@gmail.com> wrote:

Greetings Hacksphere,

I work for a small managed WordPress hosting company. We are developing a platform, which is already largely developed.

Our team is interested in some UI/UX project assistance. We are currently going through some internal design processes.

I thought it would be interesting to reach out to Hacksphere and see what's out there. We are interested in hourly contract proposals with individuals or small teams.

Please feel free to email me personally with recommendations or any questions. We can have a meeting and go over any questions or details.

The requirements for the frontend of the platform are slim. We require a suite of CRUD elements including permission management and some advanced features in the future. We are looking at React and JQuery + Bootstrap stacks.

Thank you very much,
JP Hayes

subject: Re: Autocomplete
content:
Oh man Vagrant is the most convenient thing since sliced bread... I used it
in combination with Chef http://www.opscode.com/chef/, and I could
provision a new VM fully loaded with a dev environment in about 2 minutes.

And if your normal dev environment is a headless Linux server then there is
really very little difference between SSH'ing into a box and having the
environment setup directly on your machine.


On Sun, Dec 16, 2012 at 10:11 PM, John YS <johnyangsam@gmail.com> wrote:

> @Lucas, not until you showed me. This is pretty awesome! Exactly what I
> was talking about!...Brings up another question of how I didn't know about
> the site until you mentioned it -> I feel like distribution for software
> resources is still mainly oral knowledge and word of mouth.
>
> @Jacob, I have been thinking about an easy to deploy platform since the
> pain of getting my dev environment setup at my last internship, but it
> comes down to a hardware problem, right? At the end of the day someone has
> to write spaghetti code to make a common platform (OS or otherwise) that
> everything else can build off of.
>
> Have you seen Vagrant? http://vagrantup.com/.
>
> It comes close, but I still want to have my dev env as close to the
> computer as possible and not have the extra layer of indirection with a VM
> (though that might be a silly thing for me to say)
>
>
> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 2:58 PM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>> There was a stanford startup that helped you search for code snippets
>> inline I saw at admit weekend years ago called Blueprint which got acquired
>> by adobe, and discontinued <http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/blueprint/>
>> for some reason...
>>
>> What I'm really interested in doing is creating a project I might call
>> UILabs, or UIRemix, which would let you really quickly build apps of any
>> sort in the UX-first direction. You might even be able to even mix in UX
>> elements of existing sites/apps. You could share your UX improvements to
>> existing apps online, so everybody could have their computer user
>> experiences customized like Jacob, for instance, has his customized. This
>> relates to the phenomenon that one-click setup/install is something very
>> necessary and obvious, as I expound in the email I just sent titled "a
>> modest proposal." (cmon it can take HOURS to learn to setup a service like
>> Heroku for the first time. If Blizzard were selling web dev through Heroku
>> as a game, nobody would buy it/play it if it were that hard to install.)
>> More generally, I feel like many of these UI features are very obvious,
>> and I'm curious why they don't exist already. I'm often more impressed by
>> enterprise software like Microsoft Visual Studio on this front.
>>
>>
>> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 3:23 PM, Lucas Hansen <lucashansen@gmail.com>wrote:
>>
>>> @John
>>> Have you seen http://rosettacode.org/ ?
>>>
>>>
>>> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 12:25 PM, Turner Bohlen <turnerbohlen@gmail.com>wrote:
>>>
>>>> That would be fantastic.....
>>>>
>>>> I'm sure we could convince github to donate some large part of their
>>>> website code base to begin development. I think they would love to help.
>>>> Wrap that up with a wiki, and you're good to go.
>>>>
>>>> Turner Bohlen
>>>> www.turnerbohlen.com
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 1:18 PM, John YS <johnyangsam@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>>
>>>>> How about a "wikipedia of code." One that has every algorithm in every
>>>>> language, public availably to edit in a kind of fork/pull request format?
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>> On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 9:16 AM, Carl Gao <cgao117@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>>>
>>>>>> This sounds pretty interesting - I've thought that having a side pane
>>>>>> in my IDE that is exclusively a search engine for code snippets would be
>>>>>> crazy useful. Most of the time when I search on Google or Stack Overflow,
>>>>>> I'm really just looking for example code similar to what I need to
>>>>>> accomplish anyway. Yeah - perhaps just having it as a reference instead of
>>>>>> an autocomplete feature would be more optimal, as Neal said.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> In terms of variants on common problems - you could display all those
>>>>>> options and allow the user to specify what they want to optimize for? For
>>>>>> example, upon typing "BFS(Graph G)", the IDE would ask "if you know, around
>>>>>> what size will your Graph be?" etc. Of course, the data backing this up
>>>>>> would have to be quite robust and well-organized, but it would be awesome
>>>>>> if this could happen :]
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Also, I really like how this fits into the "social coding" paradigm!
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>> On Fri, Dec 7, 2012 at 3:08 PM, Neal Wu <neal@nealwu.com> wrote:
>>>>>>
>>>>>>> Yeah, interesting idea. I don't think it would make sense for
>>>>>>> functions as high-level as BFS though, because there are lots of variants
>>>>>>> that you may or may not want to follow, and there are lots of different
>>>>>>> results you could be trying to obtain. It would work for small functions

html_content:
Oh man Vagrant is the most convenient thing since sliced bread... I used it in combination with Chef http://www.opscode.com/chef/, and I could provision a new VM fully loaded with a dev environment in about 2 minutes. 

And if your normal dev environment is a headless Linux server then there is really very little difference between SSH'ing into a box and having the environment setup directly on your machine.


On Sun, Dec 16, 2012 at 10:11 PM, John YS <johnyangsam@gmail.com> wrote:
@Lucas, not until you showed me. This is pretty awesome! Exactly what I was talking about!...Brings up another question of how I didn't know about the site until you mentioned it -> I feel like distribution for software resources is still mainly oral knowledge and word of mouth.

@Jacob, I have been thinking about an easy to deploy platform since the pain of getting my dev environment setup at my last internship, but it comes down to a hardware problem, right? At the end of the day someone has to write spaghetti code to make a common platform (OS or otherwise) that everything else can build off of.

Have you seen Vagrant? http://vagrantup.com/.

It comes close, but I still want to have my dev env as close to the computer as possible and not have the extra layer of indirection with a VM (though that might be a silly thing for me to say)


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 2:58 PM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:
There was a stanford startup that helped you search for code snippets inline I saw at admit weekend years ago called Blueprint which got acquired by adobe, and discontinued <http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/blueprint/> for some reason...

What I'm really interested in doing is creating a project I might call UILabs, or UIRemix, which would let you really quickly build apps of any sort in the UX-first direction. You might even be able to even mix in UX elements of existing sites/apps. You could share your UX improvements to existing apps online, so everybody could have their computer user experiences customized like Jacob, for instance, has his customized. This relates to the phenomenon that one-click setup/install is something very necessary and obvious, as I expound in the email I just sent titled "a modest proposal." (cmon it can take HOURS to learn to setup a service like Heroku for the first time. If Blizzard were selling web dev through Heroku as a game, nobody would buy it/play it if it were that hard to install.)
More generally, I feel like many of these UI features are very obvious, and I'm curious why they don't exist already. I'm often more impressed by enterprise software like Microsoft Visual Studio on this front.


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 3:23 PM, Lucas Hansen <lucashansen@gmail.com> wrote:
@John
Have you seen http://rosettacode.org/ ?


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 12:25 PM, Turner Bohlen <turnerbohlen@gmail.com> wrote:
That would be fantastic.....

I'm sure we could convince github to donate some large part of their website code base to begin development. I think they would love to help. Wrap that up with a wiki, and you're good to go.

Turner Bohlen
www.turnerbohlen.com



On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 1:18 PM, John YS <johnyangsam@gmail.com> wrote:
How about a "wikipedia of code." One that has every algorithm in every language, public availably to edit in a kind of fork/pull request format?


On Thu, Dec 13, 2012 at 9:16 AM, Carl Gao <cgao117@gmail.com> wrote:
This sounds pretty interesting - I've thought that having a side pane in my IDE that is exclusively a search engine for code snippets would be crazy useful. Most of the time when I search on Google or Stack Overflow, I'm really just looking for example code similar to what I need to accomplish anyway. Yeah - perhaps just having it as a reference instead of an autocomplete feature would be more optimal, as Neal said. 

In terms of variants on common problems - you could display all those options and allow the user to specify what they want to optimize for? For example, upon typing "BFS(Graph G)", the IDE would ask "if you know, around what size will your Graph be?" etc. Of course, the data backing this up would have to be quite robust and well-organized, but it would be awesome if this could happen :]

Also, I really like how this fits into the "social coding" paradigm! 


On Fri, Dec 7, 2012 at 3:08 PM, Neal Wu <neal@nealwu.com> wrote:
Yeah, interesting idea. I don't think it would make sense for functions as high-level as BFS though, because there are lots of variants that you may or may not want to follow, and there are lots of different results you could be trying to obtain. It would work for small functions like square(x), but those are easy enough that they don't cause much pain.

What I would like though would be to be able to just read code from other people that's similar to yours. If you get stuck writing something it could at least provide you with some inspiration. :)


On Fri, Dec 7, 2012 at 12:01 PM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@gmail.com> wrote:
Here's an idea I've been entertaining recently. Jacob Cole, I think this one is right up your alley.

I've seen way too many programmers write duplicate code. Code that you know has already been written dozens of times before. Code that could easily be found in a library or in an open-source project online.

Imagine using an IDE that didn't just auto-complete variable names for you, but auto-completed entire method definitions or even entire classes. You type "BFS(Graph G)" and the IDE immediately offers you the entire method definition by running a search on Git-hub.

In exchange, the IDE would politely ask you to make publicly available any non-top-secret code that you write. It'd give a whole new meaning to 'social coding'.

-- Rafael








--
Jacob

subject: Re: Looking for Alternatives to Notion
content:
Hi! I landed on Coda. It has pretty much all the features I want, the one big issue is that it lags significantly when used with large tables (10k+ rows). If someone built a similar product without this limitation, I would be very interested in hearing about it.

— Rafael

html_content:
Hi! I landed on Coda. It has pretty much all the features I want, the one big issue is that it lags significantly when used with large tables (10k+ rows). If someone built a similar product without this limitation, I would be very interested in hearing about it.

— Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Sat, Nov 16, 2024 at 3:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:
Curious what tools you landed on here @Rafael Cosman  :)

On Sun, Feb 25, 2024 at 1:51 AM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Thanks Drew- might take you up on that. I was very impressed with how you can build simple apps inside of it.

@Daniel actually worked there so I interviewed him a little about it :).

— Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 8:25 PM, Drew Bent <drew3x@gmail.com> wrote:
I use Coda all the time and it works well. Happy to answer any questions.

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 10:15 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Thanks!

Add-ons make a lot of sense for tools like this because people use them in so many different ways!

— Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 4:24 PM, Matt Vernacchia <vernamatt@gmail.com> wrote:
I use obsidian for note-taking, I like that the files are local and in common format (markdown), so (1) it's fast and works when I'm without internet access and (2) I'm not reliant on some company staying in business to maintain access to my notes. (Obsidian has a cloud sync add-on as well)

For writing formulas, it supports MathJax. For evaluating formulas, I haven't tried that, but this add-on claims to.

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 2:56 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Johannes- it seems like almost all of these apps are missing formulas?

In Tana it seems like it is a requested feature and has not been built yet. Seems like most of these other apps are in a similar situation?

How about Coda.io? Has anyone used it and if so, what do they think?

Thanks,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:27 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Wayne - I would love to, but I'm looking for speed and usability! :P

Johannes - great suggestions, thank you! I checked these out and Capacities is a WOW. Never seen a tool like that, and it immediately spoke to me. 

First thing I've encountered that could be a complete replacement to my Notion system. But would of course need to learn more, because moving over would be a giant endeavor. 

If anyone else encounters similar tools that they think are worth considering, please just add them to this thread!

Best,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 2:21 AM, W <wayneshoe@gmail.com> wrote:
How about the blockchain 

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:24 'Johannes Mutter' via HackSphere <HackSphere@googlegroups.com> wrote:
Hello Rafael,

Have you tried Tana?
It has Views like in Notion, much faster search and discovery, and a flexible graph like model:

Views
tana.inc

Anytype is another Notion contender with a focus on local first data, so you don’t query a slow remote cloud database but your own machine. It currently doesn’t have all the views like Notion has. 

the everything app
anytype.io

Another one is Obsidian, more of an outliner, but can be customized to work a bit like Notion with table or canvas view plugins. 

Some other notable mentions:

A studio for your mind
capacities.io

Build your company workspace with no code
fibery.io

The Future of Documents
craft.do

Cheers
Johannes 

On 23. Feb 2024, at 03:39, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:

﻿
Hello Hacksphere! I'm looking for alternatives to Notion if anyone has one they would recommend. The databases are one of the most important features for me, and one of my biggest complaints about Notion is that its databases are laggy and buggy. I've reported these issues to the Notion team and have not seen any progress towards fixing them.

There are things I could use Airtable or Google Sheets for, but those products are missing a lot of the other features that Notion has.

Would truly love a Notion that is speedy and bug free.

Thanks and please let me know if you have any ideas!

Thanks,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu

html_content:
Curious what tools you landed on here @Rafael Cosman  :)

On Sun, Feb 25, 2024 at 1:51 AM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Thanks Drew- might take you up on that. I was very impressed with how you can build simple apps inside of it.

@Daniel actually worked there so I interviewed him a little about it :).

— Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 8:25 PM, Drew Bent <drew3x@gmail.com> wrote:
I use Coda all the time and it works well. Happy to answer any questions.

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 10:15 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Thanks!

Add-ons make a lot of sense for tools like this because people use them in so many different ways!

— Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 4:24 PM, Matt Vernacchia <vernamatt@gmail.com> wrote:
I use obsidian for note-taking, I like that the files are local and in common format (markdown), so (1) it's fast and works when I'm without internet access and (2) I'm not reliant on some company staying in business to maintain access to my notes. (Obsidian has a cloud sync add-on as well)

For writing formulas, it supports MathJax. For evaluating formulas, I haven't tried that, but this add-on claims to.

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 2:56 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Johannes- it seems like almost all of these apps are missing formulas?

In Tana it seems like it is a requested feature and has not been built yet. Seems like most of these other apps are in a similar situation?

How about Coda.io? Has anyone used it and if so, what do they think?

Thanks,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:27 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Wayne - I would love to, but I'm looking for speed and usability! :P

Johannes - great suggestions, thank you! I checked these out and Capacities is a WOW. Never seen a tool like that, and it immediately spoke to me. 

First thing I've encountered that could be a complete replacement to my Notion system. But would of course need to learn more, because moving over would be a giant endeavor. 

If anyone else encounters similar tools that they think are worth considering, please just add them to this thread!

Best,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 2:21 AM, W <wayneshoe@gmail.com> wrote:
How about the blockchain 

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:24 'Johannes Mutter' via HackSphere <HackSphere@googlegroups.com> wrote:
Hello Rafael,

Have you tried Tana?
It has Views like in Notion, much faster search and discovery, and a flexible graph like model:

Views
tana.inc

Anytype is another Notion contender with a focus on local first data, so you don’t query a slow remote cloud database but your own machine. It currently doesn’t have all the views like Notion has. 

the everything app
anytype.io

Another one is Obsidian, more of an outliner, but can be customized to work a bit like Notion with table or canvas view plugins. 

Some other notable mentions:

A studio for your mind
capacities.io

Build your company workspace with no code
fibery.io

The Future of Documents
craft.do

Cheers
Johannes 

On 23. Feb 2024, at 03:39, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:

﻿
Hello Hacksphere! I'm looking for alternatives to Notion if anyone has one they would recommend. The databases are one of the most important features for me, and one of my biggest complaints about Notion is that its databases are laggy and buggy. I've reported these issues to the Notion team and have not seen any progress towards fixing them.

There are things I could use Airtable or Google Sheets for, but those products are missing a lot of the other features that Notion has.

Would truly love a Notion that is speedy and bug free.

Thanks and please let me know if you have any ideas!

Thanks,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu

subject: Fwd: Nanocone Glass
content:
This is some beautiful technology -- see below.


---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Paul Chen <pochuan@stanford.edu>
Date: Thu, Apr 26, 2012 at 11:35 AM
Subject: Nanocone Glass
To: Stanford Solar CarProject <solarpower@lists.stanford.edu>


Someone finally did it, Nanocone glass. This is the reactive ion etching
idea we toyed with 2 summers ago when designing the Xenith array, but we
didn't have access to fab equipment.
http://www.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/glare-dust-and-fog-free-glass-0426.html

Paul

--++**==--++**==--++**==--++**==--++**==--++**==--++**==--++**==
solarpower mailing list
solarpower@lists.stanford.edu
https://mailman.stanford.edu/mailman/listinfo/solarpower



Thanks,

Rafael

858-775-2858
119 Donner

html_content:
Thanks Drew- might take you up on that. I was very impressed with how you can build simple apps inside of it.

@Daniel actually worked there so I interviewed him a little about it :).

— Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 8:25 PM, Drew Bent <drew3x@gmail.com> wrote:
I use Coda all the time and it works well. Happy to answer any questions.

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 10:15 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Thanks!

Add-ons make a lot of sense for tools like this because people use them in so many different ways!

— Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 4:24 PM, Matt Vernacchia <vernamatt@gmail.com> wrote:
I use obsidian for note-taking, I like that the files are local and in common format (markdown), so (1) it's fast and works when I'm without internet access and (2) I'm not reliant on some company staying in business to maintain access to my notes. (Obsidian has a cloud sync add-on as well)

For writing formulas, it supports MathJax. For evaluating formulas, I haven't tried that, but this add-on claims to.

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 2:56 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Johannes- it seems like almost all of these apps are missing formulas?

In Tana it seems like it is a requested feature and has not been built yet. Seems like most of these other apps are in a similar situation?

How about Coda.io? Has anyone used it and if so, what do they think?

Thanks,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:27 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Wayne - I would love to, but I'm looking for speed and usability! :P

Johannes - great suggestions, thank you! I checked these out and Capacities is a WOW. Never seen a tool like that, and it immediately spoke to me. 

First thing I've encountered that could be a complete replacement to my Notion system. But would of course need to learn more, because moving over would be a giant endeavor. 

If anyone else encounters similar tools that they think are worth considering, please just add them to this thread!

Best,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 2:21 AM, W <wayneshoe@gmail.com> wrote:
How about the blockchain 

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:24 'Johannes Mutter' via HackSphere <HackSphere@googlegroups.com> wrote:
Hello Rafael,

Have you tried Tana?
It has Views like in Notion, much faster search and discovery, and a flexible graph like model:

Views
tana.inc

Anytype is another Notion contender with a focus on local first data, so you don’t query a slow remote cloud database but your own machine. It currently doesn’t have all the views like Notion has. 

the everything app
anytype.io

Another one is Obsidian, more of an outliner, but can be customized to work a bit like Notion with table or canvas view plugins. 

Some other notable mentions:

A studio for your mind
capacities.io

Build your company workspace with no code
fibery.io

The Future of Documents
craft.do

Cheers
Johannes 

On 23. Feb 2024, at 03:39, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:

﻿
Hello Hacksphere! I'm looking for alternatives to Notion if anyone has one they would recommend. The databases are one of the most important features for me, and one of my biggest complaints about Notion is that its databases are laggy and buggy. I've reported these issues to the Notion team and have not seen any progress towards fixing them.

There are things I could use Airtable or Google Sheets for, but those products are missing a lot of the other features that Notion has.

Would truly love a Notion that is speedy and bug free.

Thanks and please let me know if you have any ideas!

Thanks,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu

Thanks!

rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 4:24 PM, Matt Vernacchia <vernamatt@gmail.com> wrote:
I use obsidian for note-taking, I like that the files are local and in common format (markdown), so (1) it's fast and works when I'm without internet access and (2) I'm not reliant on some company staying in business to maintain access to my notes. (Obsidian has a cloud sync add-on as well)

For writing formulas, it supports MathJax. For evaluating formulas, I haven't tried that, but this add-on claims to.

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 2:56 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Johannes- it seems like almost all of these apps are missing formulas?

In Tana it seems like it is a requested feature and has not been built yet. Seems like most of these other apps are in a similar situation?

How about Coda.io? Has anyone used it and if so, what do they think?

Thanks,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:27 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Wayne - I would love to, but I'm looking for speed and usability! :P

Johannes - great suggestions, thank you! I checked these out and Capacities is a WOW. Never seen a tool like that, and it immediately spoke to me. 

First thing I've encountered that could be a complete replacement to my Notion system. But would of course need to learn more, because moving over would be a giant endeavor. 

If anyone else encounters similar tools that they think are worth considering, please just add them to this thread!

Best,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 2:21 AM, W <wayneshoe@gmail.com> wrote:
How about the blockchain 

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:24 'Johannes Mutter' via HackSphere <HackSphere@googlegroups.com> wrote:
Hello Rafael,

Have you tried Tana?
It has Views like in Notion, much faster search and discovery, and a flexible graph like model:

Views
tana.inc

Anytype is another Notion contender with a focus on local first data, so you don’t query a slow remote cloud database but your own machine. It currently doesn’t have all the views like Notion has. 

the everything app
anytype.io

Another one is Obsidian, more of an outliner, but can be customized to work a bit like Notion with table or canvas view plugins. 

Some other notable mentions:

A studio for your mind
capacities.io

Build your company workspace with no code
fibery.io

The Future of Documents
craft.do

Cheers
Johannes 

On 23. Feb 2024, at 03:39, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:

﻿
Hello Hacksphere! I'm looking for alternatives to Notion if anyone has one they would recommend. The databases are one of the most important features for me, and one of my biggest complaints about Notion is that its databases are laggy and buggy. I've reported these issues to the Notion team and have not seen any progress towards fixing them.

There are things I could use Airtable or Google Sheets for, but those products are missing a lot of the other features that Notion has.

Would truly love a Notion that is speedy and bug free.

Thanks and please let me know if you have any ideas!

Thanks,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu

I use obsidian <https://obsidian.md/>for note-taking, I like that the files
are local and in common format (markdown), so (1) it's fast and works when
I'm without internet access and (2) I'm not reliant on some company staying
in business to maintain access to my notes. (Obsidian has a cloud sync
add-on as well)

For writing formulas, it supports MathJax. For evaluating formulas, I
haven't tried that, but this add-on claims to
<https://github.com/tgrosinger/advanced-tables-obsidian/blob/main/docs/help.md>
.

html_content:
I use obsidian for note-taking, I like that the files are local and in common format (markdown), so (1) it's fast and works when I'm without internet access and (2) I'm not reliant on some company staying in business to maintain access to my notes. (Obsidian has a cloud sync add-on as well)

For writing formulas, it supports MathJax. For evaluating formulas, I haven't tried that, but this add-on claims to.

How about Coda.io? Has anyone used it and if so, what do they think?

Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu



On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:27 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Wayne - I would love to, but I'm looking for speed and usability! :P

Johannes - great suggestions, thank you! I checked these out and Capacities is a WOW. Never seen a tool like that, and it immediately spoke to me. 

First thing I've encountered that could be a complete replacement to my Notion system. But would of course need to learn more, because moving over would be a giant endeavor. 

If anyone else encounters similar tools that they think are worth considering, please just add them to this thread!

Best,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu

How about the blockchain 

On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 11:24 'Johannes Mutter' via HackSphere <HackSphere@googlegroups.com> wrote:
Hello Rafael,

Have you tried Tana?
It has Views like in Notion, much faster search and discovery, and a flexible graph like model:

Views
tana.inc

Anytype is another Notion contender with a focus on local first data, so you don’t query a slow remote cloud database but your own machine. It currently doesn’t have all the views like Notion has. 

the everything app
anytype.io

Another one is Obsidian, more of an outliner, but can be customized to work a bit like Notion with table or canvas view plugins. 

Some other notable mentions:

A studio for your mind
capacities.io

Build your company workspace with no code
fibery.io

The Future of Documents
craft.do

Cheers
Johannes 

On 23. Feb 2024, at 03:39, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:

﻿
Hello Hacksphere! I'm looking for alternatives to Notion if anyone has one they would recommend. The databases are one of the most important features for me, and one of my biggest complaints about Notion is that its databases are laggy and buggy. I've reported these issues to the Notion team and have not seen any progress towards fixing them.

There are things I could use Airtable or Google Sheets for, but those products are missing a lot of the other features that Notion has.

Would truly love a Notion that is speedy and bug free.

Thanks and please let me know if you have any ideas!

Thanks,
Rafael


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu
